Short Summary
My name is Louise Lowe. I'm a 25 year old Liverpool born photographer, and have been working professionally in the fields of Portrait, Fashion, Editorial, Music and PR for the last 7 years.  
I started my project last year, wanting to photograph the unique characters I saw each day on the streets of Liverpool and hold a small exhibition showcasing the diverse identity of this city. The project became very popular, very quickly and I decided to continue it for one whole year, curious to see how many people I could photograph throughout this time. 

The project vastly took hold when I created an interactive public event for Liverpool Light Night 2013, and had over 300 people attend the event to be photographed.

More and more people have wanted to be involved, and the turn out to each of the public open sessions has been incredible. 

Those 12 months have passed,all the portraits have been compiled and I am now ready to exhibit but this is no longer the small exhibition I first thought and after already supporting this project financially in my spare time, I now turn to you, the public to help me bring this epic collection of portraits to life.

Not only is this my first exhibition as an artist and photographer but I believe I have created a project that has brought together a community and also shows the identity of a city via the people who live here. I feel it is important for this collection to reach it's goal not only for myself and those featured and involved but also for the Liverpool public to see who they are and feel a part of something bigger.        

As well as Camp and Furnace, kindly donating "The Gold Room" to the project, Liverpool Light Night 14 are featuring it as a must-see exhibition in this year's celebration of art in the city.    
What We Need & What You Get
I need to raise £6,800 in the next 6 weeks. The majority of the funding is to cover the cost of printing the art work itself, and then the rest of the money is to go towards building the exhibition including lighting, marketing and advertising, promoting the event via posters and flyers and the distribution costs this entails, in order to reach as many people as possible.        
There are many amazing rewards for your pledges. From Postcards, Prints, Books and even your own Photo Session to commemorate this epic project coming to fruition, to also Personal, Editorial & Commercial High End Photographic and Video Sessions if you would prefer something a bit different and tailored more to your liking. I want you to feel involved in this project as well as get the most out of your rewards.    
If I don't reach my target, I have already discussed plans with the art printers to down scale the size of the exhibition. This would mean many people would not be included and it would be such a sorry waste of the hundreds of photographs that would not get to be seen that all help in creating the bigger picture.
Any further funds over my target will only lead to a bigger and better exhibition, with the possibility of the full collection being turned in to a beautiful coffee table book so the exhibition will live on once it is over.     
The Impact
This project has a chance to show the world who one city is. The people that walk its streets, which flow through its veins, the passion and creativity that keeps the heart of the city beating, the brilliant minds that keep it moving forward. Each indiviual creates its identity and these are the people you will meet in the train stations, shops, cafes, restaurants and bars, who will be at the gigs, festivals and events, and they are all important to its make up. 
Liverpool has a vast history of being negatively stereotyped and it's time to put these stereotypes to rest in this positive celebration.  
This is the first large scale project I have undertaken, and so far it has been more than successful in creating itself. The interest and support it has received has been overwhelming and shows this project is already worth a lot to so many people.
There is nothing stopping this project building on itself and doing something nation wide. Community is about including everyone and Liverpool is only a smaller community inside a much greater one. If there has been such a huge response from just one city, then I am sure there is something to be said for the rest of the British Isles.     
Other Ways You Can Help
Spreading the word about this campaign will always be appreciated. Please tell your family and friends and ask them to share it on too.  
Remember you can do this by using the share tools on this campaign. 
If you feel you want to help further, volunteers for the exhibition weekend will be needed, as well as helping to build the exhibition itself. 
I am truly looking forward to working with you all to create something beautiful.Thankyou.

story:
Fatima and I have been through many adventures together since I first took her home April 15, 2010. We have attended parties, met strangers and famous people at bonnaroo and dragon*con, and visited friends and family around the southeast. With my full time job at Ruby Falls, I have spent less and less time on my adventures with Fatima and they dwindled then stopped. In order to save Fatima from spending the rest of her days gathering dust on my dresser, I would like to take her on one last adventure together to the see the west before leaving her near the Pacific Ocean to find a new life. I would like to raise $500 to pay for gas for this excursion. Different monetary contributions would receive different rewards. Everyone would receive updates and pictures on our locations as we travel. The trip would last nine days and involve sight-seeing in the Grand Canyon and other outdoor stops along the way. Please support Fatima and me on our last quest together, planned for August 21-29, 2014

Check out some of our previous adventures at http://fatimatheboat.com

story:
"The People Tree" is a proposal for public art, to be located in the city of Greeley, Colorado.

     Hello, my name is Evan Siegel and I would love your help to complete a public art project.  I have been honored to be chosen as one of 8 artists commissioned to create a public art piece that will serve to liven up a streetscape in Greeley, Colorado.  In my excitement to design a piece that would appeal to the public art committee, I made errors in my estimation of the costs to fabricate the work.  I will receive $10,000 from the City of Greeley as part of the commission, however the total costs of the project, as outlined below, will greatly exceed that.  I am prepared to cover the overage, if needed, and meet my obligation to the city.  I have started this campaign to reach out to art lovers for some assistance.  Please read my story below.  Any help would be much appreciated, but for a donation of $150 or more you will get a piece of art!
     Within the city of Greeley there is a major thoroughfare (8th Avenue) linking downtown to the University of Northern Colorado, roughly a mile to the south.  This section of the thoroughfare has a somewhat forlorn character.  The buildings that front the avenue are intermittent and not uniform, and there is sporadic commercial activity. There is a lack of rhythm and enclosure that is not welcoming.  Because of this, traffic speeds up and pedestrians avoid the area.

     The location of the People Tree public sculpture will be where the concrete planter (without the plant) is located, directly below the Route 85 marker in the photograph.  This is a view looking north up 8th Avenue.
     The city has commissioned eight artists to create sculptural trees that will be "planted" along the avenue.  Art will be used as a catalyst to inspire changes that will make this avenue desirable.  It will become a place to visit and a place to be.  I have been fortunate to be one of the artists selected to create a sculpture.  
                                        The design I have developed consists of a tree-like form fabricated from steel. Attached to the "branches" of this tree are 13 circular galvanized steel "medallions". Both sides of these medallions will feature portraits of citizens of Greeley who have volunteered to be photographed so that their portraits may be included in this public art.   The premise for the "People Tree" is that people will be intrigued to visit a work of art that features images of their neighbors, their friends, and themselves.                                             Essentially: People attract people.      

     The images on the medallions are rendered in black and white acrylic paints and sealed with a satin varnish.  Prior to painting, a metal primer is applied to the galvanized steel.  The portraits will also be photographed prior to installation. Precautions are being taken to ensure that the paintings endure.  
     After being awarded the commission, a colleague was hired to translate my freehand drawings into a digital AUTOcad file.  This file was then submitted to a structural engineer who sized the steel and reviewed the connection details.

     The impetus for this Indiegogo campaign is simply that I have erred.  When the City of Greeley announced the call for submittals they were very specific in defining the scope and allocating an available budget of $10,000 per artist.  As I developed my design I referred to some exterior metal signage I had recently designed and installed.  I made some working assumptions, such as; If the sign pictured (below) cost 'X', then the design proposed for Greeley (above)  might cost 'Y'...                                     

     After receiving the commission I submitted the engineered drawing along with photographs of the maquette to three prospective fabricators.  It became quite clear that the cost to fabricate the proposal would far exceed the allocated budget of $10,000.  

     The photograph above shows this sculpture in late October.  The steel fabrication is primarily completed.  
     The final budget for fabrication is now approximately $18,000.  This does not include the (already paid) expenses for photography, engineering, and travel; as well as an artist's fee (my design fee).  My estimation is that final costs for all aspects of this work, including documentation and artist's fee, will approach $30,000.  The City of Greeley has agreed to a $10,000 fee.  As a consequence, there will be $20,000 of debt.  
     Launching any "crowdfunding" campaign is a gamble.  I would not embark upon this if I did not already know that I would cover the costs of any deficit, and this I am prepared to do.  I am asking for your assistance so that I might avoid this.  Thank you.
A bit about  myself:  
    I have been an artist for most of my life.  Several years ago I received my license to practice architecture in Colorado.  This particular work in Greeley utilizes my skills as an artist, my holistic understanding of cities that is reinforced through the study of architecture, and my passion and belief that a benevolent relationship between people and their surroundings is fundamental to life.
story_txt:
"The People Tree" is a proposal for public art, to be located in the city of Greeley, Colorado.
     Hello, my name is Evan Siegel and I
would love your help to complete a public art project.  I have been honored to be chosen as one of 8
artists commissioned to create a public art piece that will serve to liven up a
streetscape in Greeley, Colorado.  In my excitement to design a
piece that would appeal to the public art committee, I made errors in my
estimation of the costs to fabricate the work.  I will receive $10,000 from the City of Greeley as
part of the commission, however the total costs of the project, as outlined
below, will greatly exceed that.  I am
prepared to cover the overage, if needed, and meet my obligation to the city.  I have started this campaign to reach out to art lovers for some assistance.  Please read my story below.  Any help would be much appreciated, but for a
donation of $150 or more you will get a piece of art!

     Within the city of Greeley there is a major thoroughfare (8th Avenue) linking downtown to the University of Northern Colorado, roughly a mile to the south.  This section of the thoroughfare has a somewhat forlorn character.  The buildings that front the avenue are intermittent and not uniform, and there is sporadic commercial activity. There is a lack of rhythm and enclosure that is not welcoming.  Because of this, traffic speeds up and pedestrians avoid the area.

     The location of the People Tree public sculpture will be where the concrete planter (without the plant) is located, directly below the Route 85 marker in the photograph.  This is a view looking north up 8th Avenue.
     The city has commissioned eight artists to create sculptural trees that will be "planted" along the avenue.  Art will be used as a catalyst to inspire changes that will make this avenue desirable.  It will become a place to visit and a place to be.  I have been fortunate to be one of the artists selected to create a sculpture.  


                                        The design I have developed consists of a tree-like form fabricated from steel. Attached to the "branches" of this tree are 13 circular galvanized steel "medallions". Both sides of these medallions will feature portraits of citizens of Greeley who have volunteered to be photographed so that their portraits may be included in this public art.   The premise for the "People Tree" is that people will be intrigued to visit a work of art that features images of their neighbors, their friends, and themselves.                                             Essentially: People attract people.      


     The images on the medallions are rendered in black and white acrylic paints and sealed with a satin varnish.  Prior to painting, a metal primer is applied to the galvanized steel.  The portraits will also be photographed prior to installation. Precautions are being taken to ensure that the paintings endure.  
     After being awarded the commission, a colleague was hired to translate my freehand drawings into a digital AUTOcad file.  This file was then submitted to a structural engineer who sized the steel and reviewed the connection details.


     The impetus for this Indiegogo campaign is simply that I have erred.  When the City of Greeley announced the call for submittals they were very specific in defining the scope and allocating an available budget of $10,000 per artist.  As I developed my design I referred to some exterior metal signage I had recently designed and installed.  I made some working assumptions, such as; If the sign pictured (below) cost 'X', then the design proposed for Greeley (above)  might cost 'Y'...                                     


     After receiving the commission I submitted the engineered drawing along with photographs of the maquette to three prospective fabricators.  It became quite clear that the cost to fabricate the proposal would far exceed the allocated budget of $10,000.  

     The photograph above shows this sculpture in late October.  The steel fabrication is primarily completed.  
     The final budget for fabrication is now approximately $18,000.  This does not include the (already paid) expenses for photography, engineering, and travel; as well as an artist's fee (my design fee).  My estimation is that final costs for all aspects of this work, including documentation and artist's fee, will approach $30,000.  The City of Greeley has agreed to a $10,000 fee.  As a consequence, there will be $20,000 of debt.  
     Launching any "crowdfunding" campaign is a gamble.  I would not embark upon this if I did not already know that I would cover the costs of any deficit, and this I am prepared to do.  I am asking for your assistance so that I might avoid this.  Thank you.
A bit about  myself:  
    I have been an artist for most of my life.  Several years ago I received my license to practice architecture in Colorado.  This particular work in Greeley utilizes my skills as an artist, my holistic understanding of cities that is reinforced through the study of architecture, and my passion and belief that a benevolent relationship between people and their surroundings is fundamental to life.

story:
Short Summary

     Update: I am blown away by the support from friends and strangers alike. I got choked up today as I woke up to find that our minimum goal was met in just under 12 hours. I did not expect this at all. But this proof that there are people out there rooting for me is having a profound effect on my enthusiasm and output. I could not be more grateful. Thank you. The campaign will run till the 20th which is the day I leave. There are alot of perks in the way of art and song left, so we will keep it rolling.  Every single dime is needed and will go to ensure this trip is a safe success. Thanks again!  

        

     Hello! My name is Andy Herod. I am an artist/musician living in Asheville NC. Recently through the help of some west coast friends and supporters of my art, I was offered a solo show at a gallery in Los Angeles. This requires me and my dog driving 2300 miles across country in a van loaded down with 50-60 paintings. My van needs a tune-up and new tires. And gas is going to be insane. I'm 100% DIY these days, but sometimes DIY also means asking for help. The cost so far of just making this show has been huge to me, because I want it to be awesome. The time I'm taking off of working at home is also going to hurt. So I could really use your help in getting us there and back safely. But, I'm no charity case sirs and madams! If you give, I give!

What We Need & What You Get

     I am asking for the bare minimum of what I figure I will need to help in this undertaking. So rest assured that every dollar you spend will go DIRECTLY to helping make this happen. If I should exceed my goal, all the better. I'll need it. Trust me.

     In return for your help I'll have everything from psychic high fives to a customized family portrait for you in my weirdo style. I'll have tee shirts, screen prints, I'll even write you a song.

Check out the perks to see the goods.

The Impact

         The impact of your contribution of even a few dollars would be monumental to me. My freaky-skully-south-westerny art aesthetic has been pulling me toward the west coast for several years. But I haven't had a solid opportunity to showcase myself like this until now. This opportunity will allow me to introduce myself to a whole new art world as well as meet people who could potentially open up new opportunities for me and my fledgling art career. 


    Risks & Challenges

         The opening is October 25th which leaves me very little time to prepare, but I have a great head start already. With your help, the stress of the van won't be as much of a factor, allowing me to focus on bringing it as hard as possible. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

       Believe me. If you are unable to contribute monetarily, I understand. But if you are a fan of what I'm trying to accomplish or if you are just mainly concerned for my dog's well being on the road, use the indiegogo share tools or pass this link along to help out. I sincerely thank all of you for talking the time to hear me out. May you be eternally blessed.

story:
Dear Friends of the BOX,

Every year for the past 10 years, we have hosted an in-person silent auction fundraiser, the Empty BOX. This year, our 12th year in operation (Senior Year!), we had an amazing prom themed party planned, took "Senior Portraits" of our Artist Members, and we were so looking forward to seeing your “Prom” outfits and crowning our royal court. Aside from being a giant celebration of all things BOX 13, the Empty BOX is also an opportunity to bid on artwork by local artists, and provides vital funds that keep us sustainable.

Image: "Senior Portraits" of BOX 13 Members for cancelled Empty BOX  in-person event

 

BOX 13 Needs Your Help!

In March of this year, we closed our doors to the public due to to the Covid-19 pandemic. This was an easy decision, as the health and safety of our Member Artists who studio with us, and that of our guests and exhibiting artists, is of utmost importance. The more difficult part was having to figure out what would replace the Empty BOX, typically held the first Saturday in May.

BOX 13 ArtSpace is a 100% volunteer artist run non-profit. 70% percent of our expenses are paid by Member Artists who rent studio space and, in turn, commit to help run the organization. The other 30% of our expenses come from our exhibition spaces and facility costs, and are paid through our annual fundraiser and grants. This additional support and fundraising goes directly to maintaining the exhibition spaces, programming public events and building maintenance. Simply put, without the money raised from the Empty BOX, we cannot continue.

 

Image: The Empty BOX 2019

 

Our Mission

At BOX 13, our mission is two-fold:

  1. We present 20+ exhibitions each year showcasing 30+ individual artists within our 3 interior gallery spaces, and outdoor mural wall. Our annual open call for exhibitions is always free to apply to, and we do not take commission for works sold. The goal of our exhibition spaces is to provide an experimental space for emerging artists.
  2. We provide affordable studio space for more than two dozen local artists. We currently have 22 artists who work together to advance our mission. Our affordability helps us provide work space for emerging artists just out of school, for established artists newly relocated to Houston, or for local artists who consistently contribute to Houston’s art scene. For information on the artists currently working out our studios and their projects, visit our website.

 

Image: BOX 13 Member Artists collaborating on Subscription Artist Cards

 

Building Community

In the future, we are committed to continuing to foster connections between artist communities by participating in city wide events like Fotofest, Latino Art Now! (LAN!), and PrintMatters, as well as exchange exhibitions where we partner with organizations similar to BOX 13 across the country. This year, we presented our first ever open call for a fully-funded public mural project on our 103’ x 17’ exterior wall. Our last exhibition before the pandemic featured over 70 artists and was an international juried exhibition for LGBTQ, multicultural, and Women’s Caucus members of the Society for Photographic Education. Our mission is to continue to bring engaging exhibitions to our great city.

 

Image: Mural by Margaret Nicole Braun

 

How to Support BOX 13!

Just as with the Empty BOX silent auction, through this Indiegogo campaign we would like to provide you with an opportunity to begin or enhance your art collection while supporting what we do. In exchange for your support, we have a selection of artworks from BOX 13 Member Artists that will be updated weekly, as well as limited edition perks like enamel pins, BOX 13 artist-designed koozies, mugs, totes and T-shirts.

We know what a difficult and uncertain time this is for most everyone, and we understand that there are many individuals and organizations in need. We appreciate any act of generosity or support. Your gift, no matter how humble or generous, will allow us to continue to thrive as an organization and be a resource for artists in Houston.

Thank you for supporting us in reaching our fundraising goal. We miss you, and hope to be able to welcome you back soon.

Sincerely,

The Member Artists of BOX 13 ArtSpace

Emma Balder, Alberto Careaga, Angel Castelán, Claire Chauvin, Sandra de la Rosa, Farima Fooladi, John Forse, Jennifer Greenwell, Daniela Koontz, Jessica Kreutter, Nicolle LaMere, Melinda Laszczynski, Alex Lesser, Emily Link, Ruhee Maknojia, Tudor Mitroi, Venessa Monokian, Patrick Phipps, Javier Pulido, Caroline Roberts, Alexander Squier, and Nohelia Vargas Bolivar

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

story:
Sometimes human lives are more important than justice.

Smash the fash. It's what our beloved Masked Hero was built upon.

Show the world you won't put up with fascism with these Henshin Hero inspired enamel pins.
Each 38 mm pin is made with Black Dye soft enamal for striking black outlines on the artwork, easily readable without glare from your jacket of choice. Each perk comes with a vinyl sticker of whichever pins you receive.

Maybe you've seen something similar before?

In 2019 I produced an initial run of pins featuring designs like these.

This time around I wanted a slight redesign that looked a little slicker than their previous counterparts.

 

Line Up

 

 
This campaign is pretty straight forward, it's a preorder system for this run of pins. The goal is the amount I would need to produce a decent amount all pins in the set. Should this campaign pass its initial goal I'll start adding extra pins for backers, including an oversized pin with all 3 Riders.
 

Stretch Goals

 

When preorders for the Kicks pins reach £800 I'll be adding a mini pin to everyone's order.
This pin will be around 20mm

The 3 rider pin, rather than being enamel due to the extra details will be a printed pin on a metal backing with a clear epoxy coating, 40mm in size. Available to everyone who backed to get all 3 pins as a bonus and also available as an extra tier on its own if we reach £1000.

About the Artist

 
Bozo Robo is an illustrator/ merch producer. They've been running their online store since 2018 and have been making enamel pins, patches and tees inspired mainly by Henshin Heroes from its launch. Bozo Robo also dabbles in comic books and card games.

story:
Remember when people wrote letters and sent postcards?

 

In the aftermath of 9’ll, with my beloved City scarred and my 7th Avenue studio lost, I packed my cat and went driving across the country, unsure of where my life was heading.

 

For years I had been writing and mailing postcards for the postmark, then collecting the cards from the recipient as part of a long-standing art project. During my cross-country sojourn after 9’11 I sent postcards from the different states I visited, each postcard a memory and memento of the places I visited, what I had experienced and felt. 10,000 miles of road and three months later, I returned home to New York but without my cat. She stayed in Las Vegas with my dad and mom.

 

This is a Book Publishing and Art Show Project of a collection of 52 postcards that were made during 1995 to 2002. The postcards are snapshots of my travels, thoughts and my relationships, composed in an artful way. Each page of the proposed book has a copy of a card with an accompanying transcription of the card.

 

This project will cost $15,000. as it is a two part project first publishing the postcards will be reproduced with the best quality digital imaging 52 postcards and most are two sided. The second part of the project is the gallery. The costs are still being negotiated, and could run more than the projected because of the framing issues, as the postcards are 2-sided, estimated cost $8,000. I am still looking into spaces, though I now have a few spaces that are interested!

 

  • Launched: Aug 5, 2013
  • Funding ends: Oct 3, 2013

 

I write very cryptically using symbols and pictures, writing both forward and backward, even upside down. This will be written and also translated so it can be read. 

Please follow this link to view examples of the postcards.

 

http://www.lmzilker.net/projects.html You will see that these postcards are very personal! Each was done in not only different states of the U.S, but in different states of my mind. The postcards capture some very trying times in my life, including 9’11, the loss of my studio and my road trip across the country on my own, wondering what to do next.

 

I feel that postcards aren't just there to let people inform their family, friends and colleagues about the cool or important place they've just visited in another state or country, but that postcards are also a deeply personal and intimate way of communicating, generally.

  

This is an Art Book not a regular book ie no plot, not a story per-say but a collection of mini stories; a coffee table art book; there would B an art show at the end of the publishing part the postcards are two sided artworks that would be hung in the middle of the room or free standing so people can walk around and see both sides. Then buy or take home the artwork at the end of the show! 

My greatest hope would be for the show to be picked up and shown in other galleries. All help is greatly appreciated, thank you! Please spread the word so I/we can show that postcards still have a place in art, and that sometimes the past can be part of the future, in art and in life."

I understand that some people just can't contribute, but you can help by sharing the link and spreading the word, also you can share the info by using the Indiegogo share tools!!

 

All help is greatly appreciated. Thank you!!!

story:
Thanks, guys! <3



What's this about?

This is a project I plan to complete before the end of the year: Drawing and painting and cutting and gluing (and whatever the heck else) mixed media pieces to send to those backing this campaign. I hope it will help me improve my skills and I can spread a little art-love to more places in the world.

Funding for this project is flexible because you can only use PayPal for fixed funding, and the Indiegogo help centre says, "PayPal recently implemented a policy that places a block on any account that pre-sells goods for longer than 30 days without fulfilling them. The criteria to lift the block will vary for each account. In a worst-case scenario, PayPal could start reversing payments, sending contributions back to contributors. If you are not sure if you'll be able to ship goods within 30 days, consider disabling PayPal as a payment option."

The perks for this project will not be sent out within 30 days and may take until the end of the year (the project deadline is 31 December 2013), so I think it's better not to risk a potential incursion from PayPal. Not reaching the goal shouldn't get in the way of the project being fulfilled, -- though let's still try to make it!

Please check out the gallery for examples of some of my work. Thank you! (Note: There is some nudity.)

Have you done anything like this before?

I've done two projects similar to this on Kickstarter; one is 100% complete, the other will be finished before the end of October. Though my second one isn't complete yet, the first one (Circus Girls Sketches & Paintings) was completed on-time without a hitch. 

I used to sell my artwork on Etsy, but recently moved to Storenvy. I've also participated in private swaps with people on Flickr and swaps on Swap-bot (mostly art cards).

What are the perks?

You can see the perks to the right, but I will explain a few more things in detail here:

Shipping - Shipping costs need to be added to your funding amount for your item(s) to be shipped, so please don't forget them. If you do forget, I can accept it through PayPal.

Art cards - If you don't know what an art card (ACEO/ATC) is, you can read about them here.

Surprises - The surprise options are just as they sound: They're surprises! Who doesn't love surprises?!

Themes - The theme options are below. When selecting these options, you may also request small things like hair colour, eye colour, skin colour, or freckles if you wish.

• Science-fiction/space/aliens
• Circus/carnival
• Fantasy
• Steampunk
• Hallowe'en/occult/witchy
• Alice in Wonderland/Through the Looking-Glass (books)
• Something strange (girl with bear head or mushroom eyes or who knows what else)
• Whatever/any theme/no theme

Please note that nudity may be involved. If you aren't okay with that, please let me know.

If you have any questions or ideas, feel free to contact me.

I can't fund this campaign, can I still help?

Of course! The best way to help is by telling other people about this project. I would appreciate it greatly! Indiegogo's short URL for this project is igg.me/at/eny-mm, but you can also use my short URL enygogo.does.it (which I think is tons easier to remember).

You can tell people about this project on

• Facebook
• Tumblr
• Twitter
• Google+
• YouTube
• A blog
• A bus
• A train
• A walk
• A jog
• A skateboard
• A bike
• A rampage
• Probation

Please, just share! :D

What risks might there be in funding this?

I could die or something. I think the most likely thing is that it may take longer to complete than I expected: I have really no sense of time and there may be more people backing this than expected and I am only one person. But, as I said, I've done it before. And, even if it does take longer for some reason, I will still complete the project and send out the perks. -- Unless I die beforehand, in which case I apologise; if it's any consolation, I have no plans to, especially since I'll have a project to complete and perks to send!

story:
Summary

Riddle Farm Glass is a glassblowing studio that was started in 2007.  We use glass mined locally to create beautiful pieces of art which bring functionality and joy into people's lives. We produce glass products ranging from small jewelry items to large glass vessels, ceremonial art, and ornamental pieces. 

We've created this campaign to raise the necessary funds to rebuild our glass furnace, a new kiln and ventilation system. In renewing this enterprise, the expanded studio will enable us to reach deeper into the community, providing education and hands-on studio experience to local artists.

Vision

My name is Kristen Marie Munoz. I began blowing glass in Austin, TX thirteen years ago, using a torch and borosilicate glass. I moved to Western North Carolina shortly after to attend the Penland School of Crafts. There I practiced with and learned from Emilio Santini, Thurman Stattum, and Alan Fine among others. I attended sessions at Penland for eight straight years before I helped build my own studio in Marshall, NC in 2007.

Riddle Farm Glass is an environmentally and socially conscious business. I use local glass mined within 40 minutes of our studio. Nearby Spruce Pine, North Carolina is known to have some of the purest quartz in the world and their quality of glass is very high. Along with Spruce Pine Batch Glass, I use different minerals and metals to infuse unique designs and patterns in my glass art. My work includes giving back to the earth by having trees planted with each customer purchase while raising awareness of environmental issues.

Glass blowing as an art and small enterprise has been gradually dying over recent decades due to the high costs associated with operating a traditional studio. Therefore we are committed to raising awareness about glass blowing as an accessible artfom by opening our doors to tours, small group demonstrations, classes and individualized instruction.

Along with making functional art which brings joy into people's lives, we create custom ceremonial glass for people of all faiths and traditions to incorporate into their spiritual practice.

What We Need & What You Get

The furnace I helped to build in 2007 now has a cracked crucible. It needs to be taken apart and completely rebuilt. The materials needed to operate efficiently under temperatures in excess of 2,000 degrees fahrenheit are expensive. We discovered in 2007 that the cost to build the furnace ourselves was drastically lower than purchasing a new unit.

I am so excited that you want to support the new vision of Riddle Farm Glass! Feel free to contact me if you have a special request that is not covered in these options:

  • $5 studio tour and gallery stroll

  • $25 ornament 3-4 inches and studio tour

  • $50 fairy ball (8 inch ornament) and studio tour

  • $100 garden globe on steel post and studio tour

  • $250 custom piece and come to studio to craft your own piece of glass

  • $500 weekend long course in studio all materials included

  • $1,000 or more gives a week long course in glassblowing studio with full time instruction between 3 instructors

story: ```

Kate Brittain. Morgan Hood. Courtney Murray. Adrienne Risborough. Florence Thomas.


Room131 is an all female collective studying at Camberwell College of Art, together we plan to conduct an exhibition in the month of May this year in the London area. Also we will be putting together a publication to aid the exhibition and provide more details into the works and the artists involved in the show. We are interested in looking at the history of the area of London that we are currently living in and are calling ‘home’ and reflecting that within our separate work. None of collective are originally from London so we will be looking at the areas from an outsider’s point of view, some of us have only lived in these areas for 5 or 6 months, but it’s home to us whilst we’re here, yet it is not the place we were brought up in and we’re not around the people and the environment that initially shaped our personalities and our behaviors. As a group, many of us also make trips back ‘home’ to visit family whilst living in our ‘home’ in London, which creates another use of the word ‘home’, living between two places and yet feeling in so many ways that we have moved away from our families with no intention of living with them again. We need your support.

The publication will almost be like a mini biography on each of the artists, looking into where we’ve come from, our lives and where we are now living within London. As a group we all come from different backgrounds and different areas of the UK, however we all came together to study BA: Drawing and we are living within the South, South East & East of London.


The Impact

We are hoping that our project will be inspiring to a wide range of people, there are numerous universities across the city of London, with their students not all having come from the London area originally, so our aim is for them to be able to see where we are coming from and what we are trying to say within our pieces so they have the chance to relate to their own experiences. We are also aware that London is a very multi cultural city, we are not the only ones who have moved away from our families to create a new life for ourselves within London, in fact a lot of people have come much further than us and have their own stories to tell about where they have come from and how it is different. In many ways London’s history and British culture is become lost within the developments and expansion of the city both physically and culturally, and we’re interested in finding those things within the areas we are living for people to see and become aware of once again.
In order to realize our goals for this project we will need to work with several external partners. The ideal space we require would be a small gallery, disused shop, a uninhabited house or perhaps a church, all of these places will have a price that we will have to negotiate. Also, the other main party we will have to work closely along side is a printers for our publication, and advertisement flyers, business cards and artwork prints.


Your Contributions

Big or small, your contributions will make this happen! Give just £20 for a unique print and warm Thank You. Or receive a signed, limited edition print from one of our artists work. Check out our other incentives ranging from £5 to £100. Our largest contributors will have a special thanks at our private view.


Where will your money go?

  • Venue rental and preparation for a week long exhibition
  • Building utilities and maintenance
  • Printing and posting
  • Reception catering


    • Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

    • Ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about our exhibition.
    • Support us on social media @131_Room.

story:
Short Summary

  • Outsider Artists Michael X. Rose and Scott Michael Ackerman
  • We're hoping to raise funds for a pop-up gallery exhibition in Beacon NY
  • The Rewards are fantastic: Original Paintings at special fund raising prices commissioned for and by you. Also T-shirts, Books and more.

What We Need & What You Get

The Break Down in detail:

  • We need 1200$. 1000$ is for the rental of the exhibition space. 100$ is for promotion postcards and another 100$ for opening night refreshments.
  • Our perks are INSANE! We're painting specially commissioned paintings for you on subjects you choose. We've cut our prices in half for this special fundraiser. Strike now to commission a painting at a 50% discount!! This opportunity won't last.
  • If we don't reach out entire goal, what we raise will defray the costs of the gallery rental. We'll just have to hustle more to sell more art during the exhibition. But you can pre-order now at drastically reduced prices!!!

The Impact

 This is the dramatic difference your contribution will make:

  • You will help make an exciting art exhibition possible and be listed as a contributor. New, original, and exciting artworks will be created specially for you. Beacon is an exciting town for art and only 1 hour from NYC by train. This is a chance to help these great artists reach a new level of art presentation. Michael X.  and Scott can increase and grow their audience with your help. 
  • Michael and Scott have successfully raised funds in the past for booths at Fountain Art Fair several years in a row.
  • We've done this successfully before and can't wait to see the installation and make new friends in the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways you can help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Please share this link! Thanks and God Bless!

story:
I'm a 25-year-old London-based fiction writer. I write short stories, novels and plays. I've wanted to go to the Arctic since I was 11 and read Philip Pullman's 'Northern Lights'. 

In a city like London, it’s easy to mistake what you get caught up in as the real world. I just want to experience our planet at it rawest, and the expedition feels incredibly important for its honesty.

That’s all I’m going to say about feelings.

The Arctic Circle is not an ice hotel residency or a polar bear safari: it’s an opportunity for artists and scientists to collaborate and experience an extremely remote, raw and endangered part of
our planet.

 

This is how I came across The Arctic Circle:
 

Over breakfast one of my housemates, Lewis, asked what I would do in an ideal world.

I said: Go on an expedition to the Arctic and write life-changing fiction off the back of it.

He said: Well, Why Don’t You.

I said: Because I write fiction and I’m skint.

He said he had met someone once who had applied for a residence especially designed for artists in Antartica.

I spent the morning in my room googling variations of ARCTIC - ARTISTS - EXPEDITION - 2017.

Then The Arctic Circle popped up and - Oh Boy, I knew, This Is It.
 

The Arctic Circle residency is specially designed for science and art to work hand in hand. If selected, the participant agrees to raise $6300 USD through sponsorship.

Well, we would get to that hurdle if we ever come to it. I put together a creative portfolio which included a sample of the novel I have just finished writing.

I was shortlisted. It was glorious beyond imagination.

The acceptance e-mail from the director Aaron O’Connor came through one month later.

 

The expedition: 1st - 19th October

Come payday, I booked my flights to Longyearbyen, Svalbard, one of the world’s northernmost inhabited areas. On October 1st we’ll set sail from Svalbard on a traditionally rigged, ice-class tall ship our home for the next 18 days.

 

The expedition is led by Aaron O’Connor, NY based director of The Arctic Circle. 

As the expedition takes place in October we will experience both day and night, sunrises and sunsets, stars and auroras.

This project stands out as a discussion between scientists and artists of different disciplines. For myself, it’s a way to understand the nature of our planet and scale of the destruction we are causing. Strip away civilisation and we’re down to basics. This is a single opportunity to draw attention to the most extraordinarily dramatic issues happening right now. There’s just not enough emphasis on global warming. I think there’s more than enough evidence that we, humans, are capable of hideous destruction and extraordinary kindness.

Scientists aren’t enough. This expedition is a way of drawing in a wider audience, in the hope that artists can tackle the situation from different angles.

 

The money:

Cost breakdown The $6300 USD (£5k):

• Longyearbyen lodge accommodation, (pre and post sailing and only within programme dates)

• Transfers from airport to lodge, and lodge to ship

• Accommodation on board ship from our point of departure to return

• All meals on board

• All shore excursions

• Access to onboard facilities

In terms of equipment, I want to be minimal: layers of thermal clothing, a notepad, pens and a camera.

I have found crowd funding a hugely supportive platform in the past. It’s an ideal way of letting people know what you’re doing and involving a wider audience. Previously, through crowd funding, I have managed to take a play to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and organised activities at work, which have collectively raised just over £5k for the Counterpoint charity (including a 26-mile hike over the Yorkshire Three Peaks and a sleep out on the streets of London).
 

You can follow my progress on this page, and see what I'm doing in order to raise awareness and sponsorship for my campaign. If you would like to donate directly on this page, I would be extremely grateful. If you have any suggestions or donations, please get in touch with me directly. Should I surpass my total, I’m going to use every penny to support myself as a writer and get projects on their feet once I’m back.

Experience fuels stories. An expedition to the High Arctic aboard a ship is going to be one hell of an experience.

 

Thank you, Philip Pullman, for planting the seed of the North. Thank you, Thank you, Leone Ross, for my wonderful letter of reference to The Arctic Circle Organisation. Thank you, Lewis Bench, for the chat over breakfast that morning.

story:
Were you there?

Did you feel the rhythm rip through you when the DJ laid it down and made everything feel so good?  Did your arms and legs move in secret rituals that you made up on the spot?  Did your lips float irresistibly upward into a smile that you never wanted to end?  Do you remember how wonderful it was, and how you couldn’t wait for the next one to come around so you could do it all over again?

Did you rave?

Hi. My name is Michael Tullberg, and I’m one of the longest-running electronic music photojournalists in North America. During the 1990s and 2000s, I was writing and photographing for most of the major dance music magazines in this country, covering the hottest and most controversial music scene in the land: the rave scene.

That’s right, the rave underground. The secret dance music network. The parties that were so intense, they became instant classics as their growing legions of fans raved happily well into the morning on a regular basis. And now you can go back to those heady and fantastic days by contributing to fund my new book, DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM: Land Of The Free, Home Of The Rave.

Electric Daisy Carnival, 2001

DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM: Land Of The Free, Home Of The Rave is about the glory days of the American rave scene as it exploded nationwide like wildfire. It's a photo-heavy book that contains hundreds of my very best images from the formative years of epic parties like Electric Daisy Carnival, Nocturnal Wonderland, Dune and others. It gives you VIP access to legendary electronic music artists like Paul Oakenfold, Moby, Fatboy Slim, Carl Cox, Richie Hawtin, the Chemical Brothers and more. 

The author Michael Tullberg and the one and only Carl Cox, 2000 or so.

DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM will take you back to the warehouses, deserts, mountains, beaches and clubs where rhythmic magic was made. In other words, it's a rave hot tub time machine.  And, this campaign is the ONLY way that you can reserve your copy ahead of publication.  So pre-order with a donation today!

Richie Hawtin, L.A., 1999

Dune 4 desert rave, 1998

And here's some more from Frankie!
“Michael Tullberg is a long time photographer of the west coast scene. He has been trying to fund his book project for some time now and I think anyone who truly loves this culture should help this guy out to live his dream. Unrelated to STORM, yet totally related to PLUR, just take a look, and spread the love.”

DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM: Land Of The Free, Home Of The Rave is going to be the first photo book of its kind in the U.S that presents the visual record of a crucial era in American pop culture. The first to show what raving was really like, from the point of view of those who were actually there, as opposed to the outside academics and press who could never fully (or accurately) describe what was really going on.


BEHIND THE SCENES!! An *exclusive* story about the secret party world of SUPERSTAR DJ KEOKI and SANDRA COLLINS! Prepare to laugh!

DJ Donald Glaude and fans at JujuBeats, Southern California.

Trance-master DJ Christopher Lawrence gives a great shout-out!

WHAT ARE YOU PAYING FOR? The printing of the book. Getting thousands of photo books of 300+ pages made on high-quality paper isn’t exactly cheap, as you might expect. Thus, this is where the money is going—the making of a high-quality product meant to last a lifetime on the shelf or coffee table of any electronic music or pop culture fan.

Dune 4, 1998

**RADIO ALERT!!** Click the link below to hear Michael being interviewed by Swedish Egil on POWER106's "Powertools" EDM radio show! You'll hear him talk about this campaign at 1:27:00! (That's one hour, twenty-seven minutes in)

PowerTools link


Ken Jordan from THE CRYSTAL METHOD gives his support, and recalls the day when he first met Michael Tullberg!

And as you can see, we've got a bunch of cool rewards for those who choose to support this project. Of course, the biggest reward is the book itself, which you can reserve for yourself with a donation. You'll be avoiding the shipping costs that are normally included in shopping online, and California residents get a special bonus: NO SALES TAX!  And that's not all! You can also receive CUSTOM PHOTO PRINTS of several of the images appearing in "DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM", in 5"x7", 8"x10" and 11"x14" sizes! You can even get a Skype photo seminar with yours truly, where I'll tell you the secrets of creating fantastic nightlife photography!

John Digweed at the Viper Room

If we exceed our target donation amount, we're certainly open to stretch goals.  We definitely want to meet the demands of the fans of the music, so if we take in enough to expand the initial printing beyond our planned amount, that becomes a distinct possibility.

Look! A great shout-out from DJ Jason Blakemore, one of the classic old-school Southern California rave DJs!  Jason has been playing in the scene for as long as I can remember, and it's great to get such a nice recommendation from him!  Way to go, man!!

***UPDATE!!!*** The legendary DJ/producer Swedish Egil talks about one of the great rave haunts of all time, the Alexandria Hotel in Downtown L.A.--which has its own chapter in "DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM: Land Of The Free, Home Of The Rave"!


People sometimes ask me, "what was shooting a rave really like?" Here's my answer!

OH WOW HUGE FRICKIN' UPDATE!!!!

Check out this new AMAZING article in SLATE.COM! This is a huge deal, folks, because this Slate article is quite likely the very first article from a major mainstream news outlet (NOT  a music one!) that has profiled the crowdfunding of ANY rave-oriented project! And take a look at the great gallery of photos they included! Click the link below NOW!!!

http://www.slate.com/blogs/behold/2015/06/14/michael_tullberg_photographs_the_in_his_book_dancefloor_thunderstorm_photos.html

Here's what the press is saying about DANCELFOOR THUNDERSTORM!

·  From URB.com:  “Photographer Michael Tullberg shot hundreds of images for URB and other magazines at the height of LA’s 90s rave scene. From raves on the Venice boardwalk and downtown’s Alexandria Hotel, to the National Orange Show in San Bernardino and the desert raves all the way to Indio, no collection of photos from this magical time and place have ever been assembled before.”

·  From VIBE.com: “Every subculture includes a handful of tech-friendly souls who function as their movement’s de facto historians. Reviewing and shooting festivals like Electric Daisy Carnival and Nocturnal Wonderland for outlets like URB and Mixer,Tullberg amassed a collection of thoughts and images that chronicle Southern California’s rave scene from 1996-2002, one of its more pivotal eras.”

·  From MagneticMag.com: "If you’re either a veteran of the original rave scene, or if you’re an EDM fan who wants to see just how this whole thing came about, this is the book for you. It’s no stretch to say that there really isn’t any other book like this out there, for nobody else has captured the essence of this critical period of American music history like Michael Tullberg. If you want to explain to anyone just what the rave underground vibe was when it blew up across the country, just point to “DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM” and say, “This is what it was like.” It’s the real thing, the genuine article, and it deserves to live on the shelves of electronic music fans everywhere."

***NEW ARTICLE!***

GREAT new article in Magneticmag.com about the book!! Check it out!!!

***************************************************************

Here's the book's official web site:

www.dancefloorthunderstorm.com

***ALL Photographs copyright by Michael Tullberg***

***ALL music in the promo video by DJ Mark Lewis and his band, Interstate.  All music used with permission.***

.........................................................

UPDATE: June 29, 2015

**SUCCESS! THE CAMPAIGN HAS REACHED ITS GOAL!!!** 

DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM has reached its target goal of $10,000, and will be printed and then shipped out in the second half of 2015.

Most of what now remains involves coordinating its future arrival with our warehouse and fulfillment center. At this point, that looks like late summer or early fall of 2015, after which all pre-ordered books and bonus items will start to be shipped out.

So come take part in electronic music history, by contributing to DANCEFLOOR THUNDERSTORM: Land Of The Free, Home Of The Rave!  Yes, it really is all good.

story:
THE POPULAR STRUGGLE COMMITTEE OF BILI'N INVITES IMAGINACTION FOR TWO WEEKS OF CULTURAL ACTIVISM THIS OCTOBER.  

My name is Hector Aristizabal and I am the Founder/Director of ImaginAction.  I am alive today because of countless acts of solidarity by both friends and total strangers. With their support, I survived. I lived to tell my story. 

By sharing my experiences of political imprisonment, torture and creative struggle, I have learned that story is the biggest freedom fighter. It communicates our truth. It resists the oppressive narratives that others try to impose upon us.  Story makes meaning when things seem not to make sense. It sees our wounds. It heals our hearts.  It re-weaves community. Story creates POWER.

That's why I founded the organization ImaginAction. For more than a decade, we've traveled the world, working alongside others who wish to tell their own rich stories of struggle and hope.

Now we have been invited to occupied Palestine by the Popular Struggle Committee in Bili´n - the village that features in 5 Broken Cameras - and one of many Palestinian communities engaged in ongoing struggle against Israel’s ongoing practice of settler colonialism, military occupation and structural apartheid.   We feel honored to join with this community for two weeks of activism and cultural exchange. 

During our time together, we will share our expertise in using theater for social justice. Using Augusto Boal's Theater of the Oppressed we'll help create a Forum Theater play drawn from the real-life experiences of the people of Bili´n and we'll carry performances to neighboring villages (Nabi Saleh, Nili'n and Budrus). We'll organize a street theater event including spectacular giant puppets to participate in the weekly demonstration against the occupation. Chilean muralist Francisco Letelier will collaborate with the community in the creation of a mural depicting the story of Bili'n's struggle for dignity and freedom. We'll join with local and international artists at the end of our stay in a cultural exchange of music and theater to celebrate the Olive Harvest.

As we have done in our work in Colombia, Northern Ireland, and China, we have invited a select group of international theater practitioners to work with us in order to learn from the experience and from each other about the use of theater for community transformation. 

If you can't join us in Bili´n, you can still be part of the story. Your contribution will help make our work possible.

  THE IMPACT OF YOUR DONATION 
For many years ImaginAction has been developing different ways of using Theater of the Oppressed and other methodologies to collaborate with political and social activists, community and youth organizers, educators and therapists around the globe as a way of engaging social problems, activating communities, and experimenting with new social and political possibilities. Your donation will help ImaginAction´s team and up to 20 Palestinian artists  to come together and learn from each other as we use theater as a way of political resistance and healing. 

 WHAT WE NEED 
We will need $12,000 USD that will pay for the following items:

1. We wish to provide full scholarships to at least 20 local Palestinian artists from neighboring villages. These are theater practitioners and community organizers who have already expressed their interest in participating in the internship as well as all the events programmed during the 14 days of the residency.  Most of these artists are people we have worked with during past visits to Palestine or who have been part of The Freedom Bus organized by Ben Rivers and The Freedom Theater from Jenin.  Each scholarship includes travel costs from their villages to Bili´n, plus food and lodging for the 14 days. Some of these artists will also perform their plays during the 5-day olive harvest festival at the end of the residency.  None of the Palestinian artists will pay any fees for the Forum Theater training offered by Hector Aristizabal and Alessia Cartoni. We have calculated 13,000 Shekels or $4,000 dollars to be able to cover these costs.

2.  International flight for Muralist Francisco Letelier ($1,400) plus materials ($500) that will be used for the creation of a mural depicting the many years of the Bili´n struggle against the Israeli occupation.  Francisco will be working virtually with the community in the concept design of the mural prior to his arrival. 

3.  International flight  (approximately $1,400 ) for Ken Srdjak, puppetista extraordinaire who will travel to Bili'n two weeks prior to the arrival of the rest of the group of Internationals. Ken will bring materials ($600) and a specific plan to teach how to build giant puppets. During his workshop several giant puppets will be made with the community of Bili´n.  These puppets will be used both in the weekly demonstration against the occupation and the forum theater play that will be developed and performed at the end of our residency. 

4.  We will pay local organizer Fidaa Ataya ($3,000) for her work with the logistics during the preparation and implementation of several aspects of this residency. i.e. Coordinating travel arrangements to and from airports in Amman and Tel Aviv. Transportation inside the West Bank as we will travel to three local villages, coordinating food and lodging (for up to 10 international and 20 Palestinian artists) coordinating appropriate places for the theater of the oppressed workshops, the puppet making as well as the creation of the mural. Finally she will coordinate the 5 day Festival to celebrate the olive harvest including performances of both International and local Palestinian theater and music groups as well as the Forum Theater piece that we will develop during the residency. 

5.  Alessia and Hector will cover our costs with the contributions of the International interns.  So none of the indiegogo campaign will pay us or cover our expenses. If the campaign raises more than the $12,000 requested, additional funds will go in support of the organization and will be greatly appreciated.

 RISKS AND CHALLENGES
  As many of you know, gaining entry into the Occupied Palestinian Territories and Israel is not predictable.   With Israel's most recent offensive against Gaza - where nearly 2000 Palestinians were massacred - we predict that the Israeli authorities will be especially restrictive in who they allow into Palestine-Israel.

Our Palestinian comrades on the ground have made it clear however, that during times like this, it is crucial that we continue to unite in on-the-ground, joint struggle against the racist, colonial and militaristic structures that underpin the ongoing and brutal oppression of the Palestinian people.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
1) Spread the word: Tell your friends, family, and colleagues about this collaboration between ImaginAction and the Popular Struggle Committee of Bili'n and ask them to donate!  Go to www.imaginaction.org to learn more about this project.

2) Donate Frequent Flyer Miles! We will be able to use your miles to purchase a ticket for our puppetista or our muralist. Contact Hector at haristizabal60@gmail.com.

3) Share this campaign on Facebook: Like our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/ImaginAction/191... your friends to our Facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/492680317503537/  Spread the word using the hashtags # and #indiegogo. 

4) Share this on Twitter: Follow and retweet @. Spread the word using the hashtags # and #indiegogo.

 WHAT HAPPENS WITH YOUR DONATION
Your donation on Indiegogo will be sent to our non-profit ImaginAction who organizes this internship. ImaginAction is a Los Angeles-based traveling theater arts nonprofit that seeks to equip individuals, communities and the organizations that serve them with arts-based tools designed to lead to transformative change.  When you contribute you will receive an email from ImaginAction confirming the tax-deductible status of your contribution.

QUESTIONS OR COMMENTS?
Please contact our campaign manager Hector Aristizabal at haristizabal60@gmail.com who will be happy to respond.

 WHAT HAPPENS WITH
YOUR DONATIONYour donation on
Indiegogo will be sent to our non-profit ImaginAction who organizes this
internship. ImaginAction is a Los Angeles-based traveling theater
arts nonprofit that seeks to equip individuals, communities and the
organizations that serve them with arts-based tools designed to lead to
transformative change.  When you contribute you will receive an email
from ImaginAction confirming the tax-deductible status of your contribution.
QUESTIONS OR COMMENTS?Please contact our campaign manager Hector Aristizabal at haristizabal60@gmail.com who will be
happy to respond.

story:
The Road To Nationals 

 Hello, and thanks for the visit!  I'm really excited about this opportunity and I hope that you will be too. My name is M'Vyonne Payne. I'm a performance poet, writer and aspiring slam artist from Kansas City, Missouri.

Poetry has been a life long love and comforter of mine. I wrote my first poem when I was 8. By the time I was 14, poetry had become a hobby of mine and at age 21, I gained the courage to finally begin sharing my writings on YouTube and in public at local open mics. I was 24, when I made the realization that poetry was more than a hobby or fleeting pastime; it was my passion. I became incredibly determined to make a living it. Now at 25, I've written and self-published my first collection of poetry,  released an EP,  headlined my own spoken word tour, mentored groups of high school students interested in poetry, spoken at numerous community and anti-violence events, and I guest-host the open mic venue, Poetic Underground.


Here's The Deal:

    This August, from the 5th to the 9th, hundreds of premier performance poets from North America and Europe will convene in Oakland, California, for a week of slam poetry competition, educational workshops, and community outreach events in a festival better known as NPS or the National Poetry Slam. 


    NPS is the largest event of its kind in the world. No other slam boasts such a wide variety of skilled poets and slam artists. Regardless of winning an individual title, or having a first place team, slam poets who have competed in NPS have used the exposure to gain opportunities to perform their work in feature films, documentaries, on cable television, in commercials, on Broadway stages, and at universities, colleges and exclusive venues across the globe. This can be attributed to the availability of chances to network, workshop, be inspired and grow artistically provided to attendees of this event. To be frank, going to NPS is essential to anyone with aspirations of being a successful, professional slam artist.

How You Can Help

That brings us to the point of this campaign. I need your help to make a long-term goal of mine come true: Attending the National Poetry Slam.


My financial goal is: $1,500 (usd). Included in that $1,500 is a round-trip plane ticket, hotel cost for the duration of the slam and the registration fees for the various events that will be taking place during NPS. Because this campaign is for the funding required for me to travel to and attend this fantastic event- if we don't meet the goal- I'm choosing to refund 100% of all of the funds received. 


While I am aware of how monumental this experience can be for me, individually,  my chief concern is the advantage me going can create for my city, community and the students I mentor. It is important that I use my influence to empower and enlighten those around me. If I go, my experiences will be used to build in my artistic community. I will share knowledge with my contemporaries and continue to strive for excellence in regards to mentoring the next generation of poets.  Beyond the technical skills and abilities I will learn from NPS, if you help make this possible,  it will be a lesson and living testament to the power of dreams and provide an example of what can happen if you are brave enough to follow your passion wholeheartedly. 


The PERKS

$1 = Because I know every little bit counts, and to show my gratitude I'll make a video thanking my contributors. You can leave your real name or social media info.


$10= PDF of my chapbook, Cumulonimbus


$20= Autographed physical copy of my chapbook,  Cumulonimbus. +download, & YT/Social media shoutout.


$50= personalized poem (you pick the topic) + shout out on social media


$100= Personalized Workshop session + (pdf, download, exclusive listen to a track from my upcoming album and shout out.)


Other Ways You Can Help

    I know everyone won't be able to make a donation, and that is totally fine, I've been there, but you can still help by:


  • Getting the word out and making some noise about this campaign. 
  • Share. Share. Sharing this page.
  • Subscribing to my YouTube Channel: www.youtube.com/mvyonne
THANKS FOR YOUR TIME! THANKS FOR YOUR HELP!

Share. Share. Sharing this page.
Subscribing to my YouTube Channel: www.youtube.com/mvyonne


THANKS FOR YOUR TIME! THANKS FOR YOUR HELP!

story:
Sono Sonia Aviles. Sono anni che lavoro in difesa del patrimonio archeologico in Bolivia, oggi ho il sostegno di una grande squadra che volontariamente si è impegnata a preservare la Roccia sacra di Samaipata e valorizzare il suo ambiente. Lisbet Bengtsson ha dedicato la sua vita allo studio della pietra scolpita. Emanuela Bre' e ​​Gianni Ganzaroli si dedicano al americanismo con grande passione e con una esperienza importante.

Il nostro concetto di conservazione è integrale, perché per capire il ruolo sociale, simbolico, religioso e/o politico della Roccia, si deve conoscere l'ambiente che la circonda.

La maggior divinità lapidea degli Incas è in un processo di degrado allarmante.

In coordinamento con le autorità che proteggono il monumento, insieme a Richard Alcázar, abbiamo eseguito esperimenti per affrontare il degrado, fermarlo e ricuperare l'integritá del monumento, sia con tecniche tradizionali utilizzate fin dalla preistoria o quelle che la tecnologia ha sviluppato al giorno d'oggi.

Tuttavia, il nostro lavoro è poco conosciuto, come l'ancestrale Roccia, quindi abbiamo deciso di produrre un documentario sulla sua storia, le tecniche di conservazione e la particolare vita dell'archeologo in campo.

In un mondo concreto in cui l'umanesimo, l'arte, l'archeologia, sembrano non avere posto, chiediamo il vostro aiuto.

Io non mi arrendo, si può fare.

 

Soy Sonia Avilés. Son años que trabajo en defensa del patrimonio arqueológico en Bolivia, hoy tengo el apoyo de un equipo magnífico que voluntariamente se ha comprometido a conservar la Roca sacra de Samaipata y valorizar su entorno. Lisbet Bengtsson ha dedicado su vida al estudio de la piedra esculpida. Emanuela Bre' y Gianni Ganzaroli incursionan en el americanismo con gran pasión y una importante experiencia.

Nuestro concepto de conservación es integral, pues para comprender el rol social, simbólico, religioso y/o político de la Roca, es necesario conocer el ambiente que la circunda.

La mayor divinidad pétrea de los Incas se encuentra en un proceso de degrado alarmante.

En coordinación con las autoridades que tutelan el monumento, junto a Richard Alcázar, hemos realizado experimentaciones a fin de afrontar el deterioro. Buscamos pararlo y revertirlo, ya sea con las técnicas tradicionales usadas desde la prehistoria o aquellas que la tecnología ha desarrollado en la actualidad.

Sin embargo, nuestro trabajo es poco conocido, al igual que la ancestral Roca, por ello, hemos decidido elaborar un documental sobre su historia, las técnicas de conservación y la peculiar vida del arqueólogo en campo.

En un mundo práctico dónde el humanismo, el arte, la arqueología, parecen no tener lugar, pedimos tu ayuda.

 Yo no me rindo, se puede hacer.

story:
In Calgary, we’re proud of our entrepreneurial spirit. We also have huge creative spirit that adds to our vibrancy, resiliency and our economy. Calgarians understand the importance of the arts:  92 per cent of us engage in the arts and 79 per cent believe that arts are crucial for a vibrant, safe and prosperous city.  

For years, we’ve all benefited from strong corporate support for the arts in Calgary. But that support is in decline, unmasking a funding gap from the City itself. Calgary’s municipal support for arts organizations is the lowest among comparable cities in Canada. We’re behind Toronto, Edmonton and Winnipeg.   

And, we’re falling further behind. Corporate support has diminished by up to 30 per cent leaving many of Calgary’s unique performing and visual arts organizations and festivals at a breaking point. Our arts are at risk.

 

Art Works is 14 artistic actions to mobilize citizens and garner the support of City Council candidates to close the arts funding gap and boost Calgary’s creative sector.

Our goal is to raise $1,000 per ward for a total of $14,000, which will be matched by Creative Calgary. The total, $28,000, will fund people in the community to create 14 artistic actions, one in each ward in the city between August to October 2017.

Have an idea for an Art Works artistic action? The open call for submissions is now live at creativecalgary.org/artworks. Submissions will be reviewed by the Creative Calgary Community Leadership Team and actions will be confirmed and announced at creativecalgary.org in August 2017. The Creative Calgary Community Leadership Team meets weekly and is open to any Creative Calgary campaign volunteer. Join us at creativecalgary.org/join.

 

Your support for Art Works is the beginning of a four-month Creative Calgary campaign leading up to the municipal election on October 16.

Whether it’s a concert, a show or a community art project, all 14 Art Works actions will demonstrate the creative talent that exists throughout the city and inspire citizens to participate in the municipal election.

We hope these actions will include those running for election for Calgary City Council – all candidates will be invited to attend. Together we can build the political will for a transformational municipal investment in the arts for Calgary’s creative future.

 

Creative Calgary is a campaign to build the political will for a fair municipal investment in the arts to boost Calgary’s creative future.

Arts, community and business organization supporters include:

 

Whether you can spare $15 or $500 or something in between, your support goes a long way to help create a city-wide voice for the arts in the upcoming municipal election. Regardless of the amount you are able to donate, please consider sharing this page to your friends, family and others who appreciate the arts and understand the positive effect they have on our economy.

 

To encourage you to contribute, we’re offering some pretty great perks, including:

story:
Summary

In December 2018 I received an UGEE tablet. Everything was great, at first! It then started showing problems, the most notable being that the pen cursor would constantly jump and miss out a bit of the screen, consequently screwing up the calibration. My laptop is quite old and crummy, so I assumed it was that, or the drivers, and that it would remain fixed for a while - or perhaps the 8th time in which I had reinstalled the driver.

The tablet itself was a Christmas gift from my parents, it was agreed that the amount it cost (£300) would have to be paid back later. After trying everything, I haven't been able to solve the issue, so it could only be the fault of the hardware. I've emailed UGEE and tried to get in contact with them (multiple times, to no avail) and even if I eventually do, they will likely point out that the one year warranty has passed. Of course, I can't sell a broken tablet! So...
 

What I Need & What You Get

  • I'm going to need £300 to pay back my parents for the broken tablet, but the minimum goal you can have for Indiegogo is £500, so if that goal is met the rest will go towards getting a new tablet.
  • I'm going to be offering art up for grabs for every kind of donation! From prints, to the chance to get original artwork.
  • If I am unable to reach my goal, any money will be used paying off the old tablet.

The Impact

  • As a freelance artist, I have relied upon my tablet to help me create my work, products and commissions for clients - not having one has been a massive blow to my work flow.
  • Help an artist in need! I have found myself in a tough bind, and would greatly appreciate any and all help that I can get.

Delivery

All artwork - including prints and original work - will be sent out after the campaign has run its 60 day course on the 31st of March.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that of course not everyone can donate and that is fine, so it would mean a lot if you were able to share this message and spread awareness!

Thank you!

- Alice

story:
Short Summary

What do we do now, now that we are happy? is an exhibition and performance event, opening on 1 February at Chalton gallery in London.

The group show presents new art works by five international artists, all currently based in London. The project questions how happiness is presented and used as a commodity in our society. Through sculptures, video installations and performances, the exhibition confronts us with this individual pressure to be perfectly happy contrasted with a universal feeling of disappointment and anxiety when the happiness that we long for is never reached.

The publication, accompanying the exhibition, takes its format from health and wellbeing magazines. It contains writings on the exhibition and presented artworks, advertisements, horoscopes, recipes etc. commissioned from the artists and produced by the public in the Chisenhale Studios workshop in August 2018.

What We Need 

What do we do now, now that we are happy? is well underway at this point, but we need your help to make sure we can fully realize the project. To that end, we're asking you to help us raise £700.

We've been fortunate to receive £700 from Goldsmiths Alumni and Friends Fund, but we need some additional support to make sure we can cover our costs. Your Indiegogo contribution allows us to supply materials for the new commissions, pay artists, and fund the publication of the magazine.

What you get

Our reward offering is a personalized copy of the magazine, we want you to know how much we appreciate your support of this project. We're excited to send these goodies to you as a token of our gratitude-they'll be headed your way in March.
