story:
By evoking the Dayitwa (‘self-responsibility’ in Nepali) of Nepali youth, it is possible to leverage their technical expertise, innovative ideas, leadership potential, and vast academic and professional networks towards a unified, prosperous and peaceful Nepal.  The Fellowship seeks to foster collaborative leadership among young public service leaders so that can collectively nurture a mindset of innovation in the policy-making community of the Government of Nepal (GoN).

We have three major goals -

1.  Support public service institutions in addressing critical needs of their priority projects

2.  Strengthen innovation and leadership capacity of young policy entrepreneurs

3.  Nurture a collaborative community of policy entrepreneurs, action-oriented policy-makers and other policy experts in promoting policy innovations in public system.

During its pilot year 2013, Dayitwa initiative received 62 worldwide applications in three weeks.  7 Fellows of Nepali origin from 6 countries were selected for 6 projects in 3 government agencies, including Kathmandu Metropolitan City Office (KMC), Ministry of Industry (MOI) and Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction (MOPR).  The Fellows hailed from US (John Hopkins, U of Maryland), UK (London School of Economics), Finland (Aalto U), India (Jawaharlal Nehru U), China (Tongji U) and Nepal (Kathmandu U).


During the fellowship, the 7 Fellows visited 12 districts, gathered data from beneficiaries of government projects, consulted with local and national stakeholders, prepared policy recommendations and shared a positive message about public service with the world.  As successful outcome of the pilot year, the GoN has shown large interest in the program.  In 2014, the program will support 29 fellows from about 15 countries to work in 7 public agencies and with 11 Members of Parliament. We have already received more than 220 applications from 17 countries around the world for these 29 fellowship positions.



The 2014 partner public agencies include Ministries of Industry, Education, Peace, and Foreign Affairs as well as Office of the President, Investment Board Nepal, and Kathmandu Metropolitan City Office.  The 2014 partner MPs includes Gagan Thapa, Prakash Man Singh, and Chitra Lekha Yadav from Nepali Congress, Gokarna Bista, Rabindra Adhikari, Som Prasad Pandey and Madhav Kumar Nepal from UML, Baburam Bhattarai and Shyam Kumar Shrestha from CPN (M), Abhishek Pratap Shah from Madhesi Janadhikar Forum and Chandreshwor Jha from Independent.

story:
Short Summary

ART CASS is a working apparel business model that involves nominated artists to create seasonal collections with CASS. 20% of proceeds will directly support children in the arts.

CASS is an American shapewear brand sold worldwide in major department stores and boutiques. Established in 2004, CASS is known for its innovative seamless fabrics and attention to detail. CASS shaping tops, dresses, and bottoms are designed with patented "INVISUPPORT" that lifts, shapes and slims in superior comfort.

CASS founder Susan Ledyard is an award-winning Entrepreneur and Innovator whose mottos are "No compromise in design" and "Always involve and give back."  Ledyard has designed for Madonna, shaped many A-list celebs for film, and has been covered in national magazines including Oprah, Instyle, Fitness and more.

The first ART CASS collaboration is with nationally recognized and acclaimed textile artist Caroline Lathan-Stiefel, who creates major monumental installations for interior and exterior spaces, some 80 feet high. Her piece Tracery has been superimposed onto CASS seamless leggings.  

The ART CASS project involves artists in a successful business model to design, produce, and sell product, and this model can be replicated each season on its own.  20% of proceeds from the first sale will directly support children's art scholarship programs.  Selected this season is The Delaware Center for Contemporary Arts (DCCA) - Rachel Gambrill Scholarship Fund.


What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution will support the ART CASS process, product production, and continuing of the ART CASS collaboration program. In turn, you will receive a legging.

  • We will need $10,000 to begin our first production (design, sampling, 1600 units of leggings).
  • If fully funded, together CLS and CASS will contribute $8000 to DCCA Delaware Center Contemporary Arts to support the Rachel Gambrill Scholarship Fund.
  • Many perks are available to include you in the First Annual ART CASS Leggings kickoff.
  • Signed leggings available by the Artist.
  • We will ship your leggings to you for FREE. We will contact you once the campaign is over for your size(s).
  • You can even contribute to be a part of next season's ART CASS project.
  • CASS has supported the funding to get this project off the ground; however, if not fully funded, less $$ will go to DCCA proportionately to what we achieve in the amount of 20%.

The Impact

We are excited for you to receive the first ART CASS Leggings by Caroline Lathan-Stiefel and CASS, which in turn will help us to continue this business model for other successful artists.

  • As a contributor, you will be providing encouragement and enlightenment to economically challenged children wanting to take part in select art programs.
  • Be inspired. Be involved. Support the Arts and receive your ART CASS legging today.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We appreciate your interest, and with your help we can spread the word & inspire others to support the ART CASS Movement. 


  • View Caroline's work at http://www.carolinelathanstiefel.net
  • View CASS styles available at https://www.cassandco.com
  • Contribute to DCCA Rachel Gambrill fund at http://www.thedcca.org/Rachel

story:
Brick By Brick:

  Building Life Size Memories of the Volkswagen

  Beetle One Brick at a Time….

ME

My name is Raquel Garabeli, and I’m a visual artist from Clearwater, Florida. As a senior in studio arts at the University of South Florida, I’ve explored a variety of media, ultimately uncovering a passion for ceramic arts among the piles of lumber, fabric and scrap metal that intrigued me along the way. I love the potential that clay embodies, and I love where it leads me. I enjoy the way it feels between my fingers and synapses as I shape the clay with my hands. It liberates my imagination. The flexibility, plasticity, and limitless “shape-ability” of my favorite medium allows me to stretch my creativity and climb over, dig under, or knock down boundaries—to manifest concepts that, without clay, would otherwise exist only in my imagination.


MY PROJECT

Currently, I’m preparing for grad school with an ambitious project destined to draw from all aspects of my experience in wood and metal, but primarily designed to celebrate my enthusiasm for clay. I am determined to carve a full sized tribute to the 1970 VW Beetle from hand-pressed bricks that are fired in a kiln. The inspiration for this creation began with memories of my childhood in Brazil in the 1970’s—memories of family trips and personal faux pas that revolved around my father’s beloved Beetle. I remember Mom, Dad, three kids and a dog packed like clowns in a clown car laughing and bickering happily on the way to adventures with friends in new places. I remember learning to drive (clutch, gas, brake, STOP!!) in that very same Beetle, with a boyfriend who seemed like a great idea at the time. We drove into a brick wall, and today I drive an automatic. Thankfully Dad’s Beetle was restored, but that memory, among others, inspires my tribute to the Beetle, the 70’s, my family and my youth.

With support from instructors, peers and mentors within the USF College of the Arts, I embarked on this project by experimenting with clay formulas suitable for brick making. The clay recipe I’ve chosen balances workability when wet with resilience after firing. It incorporates sawdust to give it texture and to make it light enough for handling during transport and installation. The clay readily accepts glazes, which may be used to impart color to the project and enhance the iconicity of the 1970’s Beetle. Next, I’ll build an underlying scaffolding of wood and metal to support the clay bricks. Wooden presses will be constructed to form the bricks by hand, and the wet bricks will be stacked to the overall dimensions of my Volkswagen. Before drying, I’ll carve the stacked bricks as a single unit in order to reveal the unique automotive structure familiar to Beetle enthusiasts throughout the world. Finally, each brick will be removed, numbered, fired in a kiln, then reassembled like a three-dimensional jigsaw puzzle.


FUNDING

Completed, my sculpture will weigh more than four tons with an estimated cost of $2,950—the majority being spent on clay. Funding from the Indiegogo community will help buy the dry ingredients to formulate the clay and purchase wood and hardware to build the armature. Contributed funds will also allow me to rent appropriate vehicles for transporting the sculpture to a gallery for display in a public setting. 


THANK YOU

Thank you!!!  Thank you!!!  Thank you!!!

Please share my campaign with your friends and family.

I appreciate your trust and contribution as you are helping me achieve this goal. 

Sincerely,

Raquel Garabeli

story:
ROOTS

We created The Byway Collective as a way to honor and recognize aspiring, hard-working artists of all mediums, who work their asses off, doing the only thing they know how to do, creating art, music, photos, tattoos, clothes, drinks, stories, and—well—you get the picture.

Malcolm Gladwell’s 10,000-hour rule is the God-honest truth. Before you can ever see a dollar for your work, you have to put in the time and these folks are right in the thick of it. They have no promise that their hard work will pay off, they have no promise of reward or success, but they do have a hell of a lot of promise.

We want to sit down with these artists and talk about their work. We want to talk about craft, and their creative process. We want to know how they are navigating their 10,000 hours, how they started out, what happens when they can't find a mentor, and how things like social media have changed the creative process. But more than that, we want to give aspiring artists a moment in the spotlight. We want to recognize their hard work, their dedication, their attention to detail, their love for their craft, and their resilience. There is an entire generation of artists who are creating art silently, without any recognition. We plan to change that, but we need your help to get there. 

(Photo Credit: Jamie King)

What We Need & What You Get

We know that $9,000.00 is a lot of money, but because the three of us are all starting out, and supporting young families, we are still collecting the tools and software that we need to create something like this. Here's what the initial $9,000.00 will go toward.

  • Startup costs. From domain and email names to LLC. licensing, starting up a company costs quite a bit. 
  • Paying photographers. Each interview we publish will be accompanied by 10-15 photographs. We hope to hire good, aspiring photographers and we want to pay them for their hard work. The more we raise, the more we will be able to give them. 
  • Software. We're young. We're talented, but we're young and there is still software and tools we don't have that we need in order to produce the highest quality product that we can. Software would include Photoshop, Lightroom, advanced web tools, as well as accessory photography equipment and recording devices. 
  • Travel. Most of our interviews will be conducted over the phone, but occasionally we want to travel to an artist, meet them, see what they're doing, where they work, and produce a short video interview with them. Part of the $9,000.00 will go toward travel expenses and paying a video production company to produce a video for us.
  • Publication. In addition to our online videos, we want to produce a print journal that publishes the work of the artists we've recognized over the past six months. Each journal will be comprised of high-quality photography, poems, stories, un-read interviews and maybe a few recipes. Unfortunately, we can't publish work unless we have the money to pay for the initial publication. 
  • Marketing: As we continue to grow our community, and produce quality interviews, we plan to invest some money into marketing our website and (eventual) publication to extend our reach and readership, which can only benefit the artists we highlight.
  • Merchandise: As a way to say thank you, we'll be creating select Byway Collective merchandise. We think they're pretty damn fashionable, and we know you'll love them, but they, too, cost money. 

^ Byway Postcard Perks

If we exceed our fundraising goals, not only will be able to produce more interviews monthly, but we'll be able to secure an initial publication, upgrade our own photography and editing software, pay higher wages to the artists we employ, and procure more opportunities for our magazine that we otherwise could not afford. 

If we are unable to raise the initial $9,000.00 we have created a list of the most necessary costs to still ensure that a version of the Byway Collective is produced, even if it is limited. We'll also ensure that everyone who did donate would receive their perk. 

(Photo credit: Jamie King)

The Impact

This is an important project. Each year more and more school districts are forced to cut funding for their art and music programs, which means less children are exposed to art and creativity, music and the power of their imagination. No one is sure of what this means for our future generations, but we all know how important writing, music and art have been historically. Art has an indescribable way of changing the way we perceive the world. We need art, now more than ever, and supporting the Byway Collective will allow us to recognize and support aspiring artists. These folks are in it for the long haul. They're dedicating all their free time to their craft, and one day you will buy their book, or hang up their photography or paintings, or use their table and chairs. We hope to provide them the recognition they need to keep moving forward.

Your support means that more artists can expose their work to the greater art community in a reputable, professional manner. Your financial support ensures that we can continue to produce this website, week after week, month after month. It means that we can take risks, bend the rules, be innovative and creative, and invest deeply into the art community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Listen, we understand money is tight. If you're not in a position to support us financially right now, we totally understand. Please, don't feel bad. You can still help us out by spreading the word. Share our campaign on Facebook, write your aunts and uncles and senile grandparents. The more people we reach, the more money we can raise, and the more artists we can support. 



Special thanks to:

Parachute Productions

Jamie King Photography

Joel Ballard

Lemonjellos

Full Circle

Gregordog

Kylen Blom

story:
Short Summary

I fell just a little short on my last fundraiser and for this one I'd like to try something new…funding my business by asking people to support other cosplayers…I am curious to see how this goes.

    • Hi!! I am Katia. Or Kate. Or Katie. Or as most of you know me Princess Nightmare. I am not spectacular with words so forgive me for this.  If you have known me a really long time you know me as a friend, if you have known me for a few years you know me as a cosplayer, if you have known me only a couple years you may know me as a cosplayer half a costume company, if you have only known me for a couple months you know the huge new part of my life which is my custom accessories design (including Doctor Who, Harry Potter, Game of Thrones, other Literary references,  and other nerdy custom accessories as well as custom bridal shoes and accessories). I am not going to sit here and give you the sob story of stuff that has happened to me in the past. I hate when people do that. There is no reason for it. This is about the future. My entire life I have dreamed big but big dreams have to start small. I am an artist, I am creative and ambitious-and the next step in my life is to make things happen. 
    • In short I am fundraising for my NYCC table for custom shoes, bags, mini hats, and maybe even some OOAK dolls!
  • I would like to see if there is a way to raise money while supporting other cosplayers-three in particular who helped me tremendously with the fundraiser that just ended.
  • If this works you will not only help me get to NYCC but help the other cosplayers involved to afford costumes, cosplay is an expensive hobby

What We Need & What You Get

  • The last fundraiser fell just a bit short of my goal so giving this a little bit of a try
  • Double helping! Helping me by helping others. 
  • What you get…more pictures of girls in costumes because they will have more costumes

The Impact

Please feel free to read my campaign which just ended for more information about what I do in further detail. I do not want to torture you with another long write-up https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/new-york-comicon-booth-funding/x/4103104 

Aside from that, cosplay is an expensive hobby and these are three girls that are awesome and have helped me advertise for my business and in return I'd like to help them expand their wardrobes!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Share!
    • If there is another cosplayer who wants to be involved and you have consent I will add them in too as long as they are US based because these prices include US shipping (nothing against other countries but this is kind of a test run to see how something like this will do) OR I may run this a second time for others interested. 

    ***READ HERE***IMPORTANT

    THIS CAMPAIGN IS HIGHLY COMMUNICATION BASED!
    Each reward 
    • The cosplayers involved in this are Mistress Jessie Cosplay, Nova Dawn, and Jadababy Cosplay. Each perk will tell you what information you need to send me theprincessnightmare@outlook.com
    • You can specify which cosplayer to send something to or specify 'to any'
    • There is one costume limited because there is only one left. There is one costume that 2 of the 3 cosplayers already own-this is the reason for limitation.
    • IF you choose a reward and your cosplayer of choice has already been given that item you can choose to give it will be given to one of the other two cosplayers OR if it is a reward that has multiple options you can choose a different option
    • Yes, I know this is a bit complex but it would only allow me to put a certain number of rewards up which complicated this tremendously. 
    • All Reward/Perk Images are viewable on the Gallery tab!


    And that's all there is to it.

There is one costume limited because there is only one left. There is one costume that 2 of the 3 cosplayers already own-this is the reason for limitation.

IF you choose a reward and your cosplayer of choice has already been given that item you can choose to give it will be given to one of the other two cosplayers OR if it is a reward that has multiple options you can choose a different option
Yes, I know this is a bit complex but it would only allow me to put a certain number of rewards up which complicated this tremendously. 
All Reward/Perk Images are viewable on the Gallery tab!




 And that's all there is to it.

story:
Mic Check is an organization that connects an active community of readers, writers, and critics of contemporary, experimental, avant-garde and neglected poetry to the general public who would not regularly have a chance to encounter this certain type of art. 

Our mission as an organization is to widen the sphere of influence of writers in our community, we are dedicated to providing an open and inclusive platform for all that come to the stage. 

What We Need & What You Get

As the fall approaches and students return to schools, Mic Check is gearing up to bring many new events to the community. Not only do we put on weekly free open mics and slams, as well as weekly writing sessions, but we are currently working with local high schools to start an after-school poetry program that will eventually culminate into individual slam teams from each school, we are at work with A.R.T. for Life, an initiative of the Arts Council of the Brazos Valley to bring in artists to work with youth in juvenile detention as mentors, and we are working to expand the Texas Youth Poetry Festival as well as the Texas Grand Slam Poetry Festival. Mic Check is also hard at work on putting together a new anthology of different poet's work from the community that we hope to release in September. 

Mic Check is constantly looking for ways we can reach out into the Brazos Valley and greater Texas communities to stimulate and promote poetry, and with your help we can continue to do so in the future and even ramp up our initiatives to larger and larger scales. In addition to supporting Mic Check, there are a number of perks we have as well, just take a look over to the side.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Exposure is a great gift. Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, text message, or smoke signal! Come out to Mic Check on Sunday nights at Revolution Cafe and Bar, volunteer for Texas Grand Slam! Your support in any way, shape, and form is a great gift.

story:
Lit Crawl London

An entire London literary festival packed into one raucous ramble through Covent Garden and Soho.

 

The idea is simple: the Lit Crawl is a pub crawl where you don’t just get to sample the local brew, but also the works of up-and-coming writers, authors and poets. It was created by San Francisco’s literary festival, Litquake, in 2004, as the grand finale to its week-long celebration of the written word. It has now become an event in its own right, with Lit Crawl spin offs in New York’s Manhattan and Brooklyn, Austin and Seattle, with Los Angeles and Iowa City being added to the list this year.
Lit Crawl London will be the first Lit Crawl in Europe.

 

The founder of Lit Crawl London, Mette Risa, volunteered for the original San Francisco version of the Lit Crawl in 2010 and 2011. Amazed that such an event did not yet exist in London, she has organised the first Lit Crawl outside the US to take place on 7 September in Soho and Covent Garden, with great help from Saskia Vogel.

Lit Crawl London will be a celebration of literature and a venue for the different literary communities in London to come together to promote their work. 

What We Need 

This is what we need money for to make sure the first Lit Crawl London will not be the last one:

  • Venue hire - the venues we use are either provided free, or for a reduced fee, but there is still a small amount to pay.
  • Printing - we have to print a program with a map and details of all the different events.
  • Website - hosting and design

We are aiming to raise at least £1000, that will cover these costs. However, we would also like to be able to cover travel costs for all the participating authors and poets. If we get less than our aim, the organisation will find it harder (though not impossible) to produce the next Lit Crawl. If we get more, we can make the contributors a little happier and make sure next year's Lit Crawl will be even bigger and better!

What you get

Did I mention that all the events are free? We want everyone to be able to attend the Lit Crawl, regardless of their financial circumstances. Any contributors will be thanked on our website (unless you choose not to), and probably in every divine afterlife you choose to believe in (not really up to me though, but if it was...).

Why does literature matter? I found this explanation online, that covers it pretty well:

Literature helps us understand and make sense of the world around us. Through literature, we explore the human condition and analyse how and why people think the way they think and feel the way they feel. Literature enables us to develop our minds analytically and promotes open minds. We see the world through the eyes of different writers from different cultures and in turn learn the ways to deal with things happening around us. Without literature, we lack insight and understanding of human nature.  (http://tinyurl.com/lf84ro5)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in supporting us.
  • Also, please come to the Lit Crawl on 7 September! And tell your friends, family and colleagues to come too. It's all free, remember?
  • We're on litcrawl.org/london, facebook.com/litcrawllondon, twitter @litcrawllondon where you will find details of the different events.

story:
Hi There! I am Ama Posey. I am an artist, and I am a mother of two small children. I am dedicated to pursing my ambitions in my career in the arts, without compromising my role as a mother. I have a belief, and a dream, that it is possible to maintain both of these roles, without compromising either... but the challenges are far from few! 

I want nothing more than to attend Summer Arts at CSU Monterey Bay, for a 2 week intensive Contemporary Painting course. The class is taught by leading national artists, such as Beverley Fishman, museum owners and curators-- a perfect networking opportunity, as well as a wealth of resources while I am gearing up for graduate school and starting my career as an artist. 

I have almost the entire cost covered in scholarships. However, as a mama with two little ones (and a very supportive partner), I am not ready to leave my family for 2 weeks. The only option is to bring them with me-- but family housing is not an option, so we need to fund the money needed for a single-occupancy dorm room, where my family can join me as guests. Scholarships do NOT cover this cost, leaving me with a balance of $900. 

In return for your financial support, I have a variety of paintings to offer to you! No donation is too little, anything you can give is so greatly appreciated. If you are not able to help financially, please spread the word!!! Thank you so much for supporting me, (and my brood) and the arts!

 

Please visit my website at www.amaposey.com !

story:
What is Sanctae?

"Every image says so much about the truth of real women's bodies. We all have scars and oddities. Not one photo shows a perfect body. And yet everywhere in today's society, women are bombarded with unreal images of idealised female sexuality - photographs of models with every imperfection eliminated. Ione's work is important because it reminds all women that the images we see in the media are not real."

Anonymous, 50, Dartmoor - Sanctae model


Sanctae is a photographic installation of 21 larger than life size (8ft x 3ft) female nudes that reveres real, ordinary women as saints. The series is resonant with historical and religious symbols and signs, and explores the intense emotions, expectations and sacrifices inherent in the female body's potential to give life. It creates a space of challenging reflections and revelations about issues of contemporary womanhood. 

I’ve been on an inspirational three-year journey creating 21 images ­– and am proud to say that they’re all complete. Now, in the final stages of the project, I need your help to exhibit these saints across the UK and Europe.


Detail

 

Where you come in

The Arts Council England has funded the first 65%. Can you help with the last 35%?

Please help me to get these images printed, mounted, backed and hung. Your contribution also means you’ll be a part of the final element of the project – 'the ceremonial crowning' of each saint with hand-transferred gold leaf halo. If I can reach my £5,200 target by August 2013, then I’ll be able to show the very first installation in January 2014 at the Royal West of England Academy in Bristol (www.rwa.org.uk). It will then tour all around the UK.

With the support of The White Square gallery in Berlin, I have big plans to take these saints across Europe, and eventually, to the States. And I’m delighted to have the brilliant Bo-lee gallery in Bath/London (www.bo-lee.co.uk) supporting me with these negotiations and proposals.

 
Detail of a dissected Longiflorum Lily (the Easter Lily)
 

A homage to a very special woman

My project is dedicated to the memory of Niki Pollard who sadly died two weeks after her photograph was taken. She was only 35 years old – a true inspiration and an honour to work with.

Niki is one of my saints. Her photograph was taken after her double mastectomy. This image prompted an unexpected email...

“I hope you don’t mind me contacting you, but I have just received an email from Art + Culture with a montage of your new work. I have recently had a mastectomy and chemotherapy [and radiotherapy] and you pictures really touched me.

Here is a visual representation of my poor sore chemo veins and my scarred chest staring back at me but for once it wasn’t me. But it felt like an acknowledgement of it from an empathic perspective rather than a clinical/medical one.

I'm sorry. I can’t really adequately put into words what the images evoked in me, they made me cry, but not out of self pity, but as a relief. It felt for the first time like somebody really understood the journey I have been on and was walking beside me and all of a sudden I didn’t feel quite so alone.

I sincerely hope you manage to raise the funds necessary for the installation.

Thank you for the comfort and strength your images have given me."

 

What Sanctae meant to the models

I've included some quotes from my models testimonials:

"It was, for me, a very liberating experience to work with Ione and also to feel that I was going to be part of such an exciting and all-embracing concept. I feel proud of us all and thank Ione for such a unique experience."

 "As a participant, it took a lot of courage to take part, but I did so because of my faith in the importance of this project."

"She challenges and encourages us to challenge, the ways we see ourselves."

"I felt that the integrity she brought to SANCTAE was worth risking my own personal vanity for."

"To work with Ione has always been an occasion that gets me thinking, feeling passionate and fired up, and seems to challenge me and those around me in unexpected ways. This says to me that it is worth doing."

Detail of a five week old baby breastfeeding
 

Other work

Here are examples of some of my other work and a description of an up and coming project...

I am currently in the research stages of a new project entitled Anatomica Botanica in collaboration with artist Rosie Martin, she has a number of books published with Batsford Press in conjunction with the Eden Project. The project will run from 2013 - 2015.

Ballet Shoe with Gold Acupuncture needles
Butterfly Collection II (Acupuncture needles and butterflies)
In the studio working on Butterfly collection II
Horn Boy
The Offering
Second Skin
My Bete Noire
Stallion

story:
Doors Open

Historic Milwaukee, Inc. is presenting the 4th annual Doors Open Milwaukee this year, one of a handful of such events in North America. We are expecting 25,000 visitors to make 100,000 site visits. And all of this is free to visitors!

We need your support!

  • It costs more than $75,000 to put on Doors Open each year.
  • Doors Open has the financial support of key foundations and corporations in Milwaukee and Wisconsin.
  • We rely on more than 600 volunteers and in-kind donations to contain costs.

The Impact

  • Doors Open is the only cultural event in Milwaukee that celebrates the built landscape, design, and architectural heritage of Milwaukee.
  • This event encourages visitors and residents to explore Milwaukee and new neighborhoods.
  • Doors Open Milwaukee encourages awareness of architecture and design and celebrates Milwaukee as a vibrant, culturally diverse city.
  • This event promotes a greater sense of community: it draws people of all ages and connects them through the city they love.
  • Last year, 97.5% of survey respondents said their expectations for Doors Open were met or were exceeded.

“Milwaukeeans spend most of our lives in a built environment that has been evolving for 175 years, but we rarely see more than the facades. Once a year the doors open, and the treasures in our midst will be available for all to enjoy.” - J

ohn Gurda, Milwaukee historian


    If you're not able to donate, there are plenty of other ways you can help!

    • Its not too late to volunteer at Doors Open (Click Here for volunteer info)
    • Share our campaign with others
    • Attend Doors Open and complete a survey afterwards

Attend Doors Open and complete a survey afterwards

story:
The Soul Train is my gift to the Burning Man community, and guess what?  I would like to give some more!  There's nothing I love better then driving it around, making people happy, having instant dance parties wherever I go, and bringing Old School, R&B and Disco to the Playa.  I BRING DA FUNK!

I would like to reach more people.  This campaign is for louder speakers, as well as replacing some lights that got damaged last year.  Burning Man is a loud place, and I need to step up!

I've been happy to have made such an impact at Burning Man, and I'd like to go further.  I've enjoyed adding to the experience of Burn night as well as assisting with the Critical Tit Ride After Party.  This year, I will also assist with The Soul Train World Record Attempt at The Man on Wednesday afternoon at 4:00 and The Dancetronauts Deep Playa Party on Thursday night. 

Anyone whose life has been affected by Burning Man knows what it's like to want to give the same feeling to others, and I am no different.  I've been told often how much I "made someone's Burn more memorable", and that has always been my goal.  This is a fixed funding campaign... either I do this right or everyone gets their money back.  Thanks for reading this, and I hope you can help!

story:
Who I am,

my name is Chad Fearnow, and i am starting a tattoo studio that will be unique to my city. I'm building a studio that will also serve as an art gallery. It will be a place for local artist, of all sorts, to display and sell art. I will also be a tattoo studio that will move away from what is traditionally thought of a tattoo shop. When a new client walks in, I want them to feel like they walked in to an art gallery, more than a tattoo shop.

What i need,

What I am looking for is the funding i need to get started. There is quite a bit of equipment that is needed to open a shop. I will need everything from tattoo chair, sterilization equipment, to remodel materials for the building itself. My hope is to raise enough money to use towards a down payment on a loan. 

My hopes,

I hope that this studio will be a positive addition to my city, and bring the tattoo industry into a different light. i want a place for artist to share there art, and for tattoo artist to be seen as artist.

MY experience,

I have been in the tattoo industry 15yrs and have worked in a few different shops, as both a body piercer and tattoo artist. I also have some schooling in business. I feel I have the skills and knowledge to make this an amazing studio.

story:
About FOCUS

Join me in creating FOCUS, a public sculpture about photography and how it shapes the way we see the world, at East Harlem Art Park starting on May 3, 2016. FOCUS is presented as part of Growth: Three Perspectives, an exhibition of FLUX Art Fair Public Art Projects in the Park. Be part of a major art event by helping me to bring FOCUS to East Harlem where it will be enjoyed by local community members, as well as City-wide and international audiences.


About Me 

I’m a New York-based Puerto Rican artist. Growing up in San Sebastian, a valley surrounded by mountains in Puerto Rico, shaped my perception of nature as a source of beauty, and has inspired my artistic practice. I use photography, video, sculpture and installation to transform the visual structures of nature into artistic objects. I create works of art that explore the physical experience of looking through photography and invite the viewer to reexamine his/her own perception of form, light, and space in the natural landscape. For more information about my artistic practice visit: www.josesotophotography.com

What do I want to do?

I want to install FOCUS at East Harlem Art Park, where it can be enjoyed by the public for free. FOCUS is concerned with the viewer’s visual perception and bodily experience. It consists of two large rectangular-shaped pieces, one placed in a vertical position and the other in a horizontal position. Each piece has two squared-shaped holes, which serve as apertures from where viewers can see their surroundings within a limited scope. The sculpture has a golden mirror-like surface that will reflect and project surrounding light.  When the viewer looks through the square opening, they will see an abstraction of their surroundings. By limiting the scope of their view, they can take more control over their focus of attention and see things in a mindful way. FOCUS combines the illusionism of photography with the specificity of actual forms in the space to fully engage the spectator and facilitate his/her apprehension of the work as a whole.


What will your contribution support?

I need to raise $7,000 to build and install FOCUS at East Harlem Art Park. This amount will cover the cost of materials ($3,760), installation ($2,000), transportation ($400), site remediation ($200), and de-installation ($640). I will keep you updated with the progress of the work, and reward and acknowledge your generous support.


About Growth: Three Perspectives

FOCUS is presented as part of Growth: Three Perspectives, an exhibition of public art curated by Warren James. The show features works that explore the concept of growth, in celebration of the 30th anniversary of Growth (1985) by Jorge Luis Rodriguez, which is the first Percent for Public Art public sculpture in New York City.

This is the statement by curator Warren James about FOCUS:

“José Soto is an artist that, through photography and sculpture, deals with and expresses geometric growth, as seen in the infinite shapes of layered grids and the framing devices for both humans and landscapes. At times telescopic and others monolithic, Soto frames a series of perspectives and points of view and the focal points are the visible growth in and outside the park itself. Placement may include strategic framing of the Rodriguez red steel sculpture and is designed to engage both adults and children. A key aspect of growth is horizontal distance and its counterpart is vertical mass both represented here.”

About FLUX Art Fair 2016 Public Art Projects in the Park

FLUX Art Fair is a contemporary Art Fair in the culturally rich community of Harlem. It is a dynamic artistic platform engaging an international community of collectors and those who simply appreciate art to experience the vitality of Harlem and discover emerging artists. In 2016 FLUX Art Fair will take the form of all public art with its nucleus in Marcus Garvey Park, extending east to East Harlem Art Park and west to Malcolm X Blvd. (Lenox Ave). http://fluxfair.nyc

About José Soto

José Soto was born in Puerto Rico and has been living and working in New York for six years. He earned his BFA from the Escuela de Artes Plásticas, San Juan, and holds an MFA in photography from Parsons The New School for Design. Among the awards he has received are Retrancado, fist_ART.FOUNDATION, Dorado, PR (2014), Permm Stop Public Art Project, Museum of Contemporary Art, Perm, Russia (2012), and Gold Award from B&W Photography (2006). In 2009 he had a solo show in San Juan, presented by Walter Otero Gallery and Viota Gallery. His work has been exhibited in a number of group shows in New York, San Juan, Valencia, and Pingyao. Among these shows are Camera Work, Parsons The New School for Design, New York, NY (2015);Hot or Cold?, BronxArtSpace, Bronx, NY (2015); Art INCUBARTE 7, Museo Valenciano de la Ilustración y la Modernidad, Valencia, Spain (2015); Muestra Nacional de Arte, Instituto de Cultura Puertorriqueña, San Juan, PR (2015); Región 0: Video Art Festival, New York University, New York, NY (2013); Puerto Rico: Doorway to the Landscape, Museo de Arte Contemporáneo, San Juan, PR (2013); Pingyao Photo Festival, Pingyao, China (2011); The Culture of Now, Aperture Magazine, New York, NY (2011); 11 del 2011, Museo de Arte de Ponce, Ponce, PR (2011); and Puerto Rican Photography, Instituto de Cultura Puertorriqueña, San Juan, PR (2011). Soto has been a teaching artist for Aperture Foundation since 2014.  www.josesotophotography.com

Risks & Challenges

If I fail to meet the target I will be short of funds but the installation will go ahead. I am confident that there are enough people out there who will be enable me to be successful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this project with anyone who cares about supporting public art and artists!

Perks

Make a contribution today and enjoy one of these perks.

story:
Find me on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr and my blog.

See all the paintings available here

Hi there, my name's Chris Hubley and I'm an artist working in Bristol in the UK. I'm also transgender, which for me means I was born physically female but identify and live as male.

Last month I started making paintings of my genitals in a project I've titled "Man C*nt: intimate self portraits of a transgender man". These paintings are an expression of my sexuality and my relationship with my body as a trans man, and a celebration of how far I've come in terms of this relationship. By painting something that is usually considered to be a private and hidden part of ourselves I hope to also bring issues of transgender identity and sexuality into the open and confront the viewer with something they may not have experienced before.

It was a surprise to me that what was such a personal project seemed to resonate with a lot of people - I published a blog post about it at the end of August which got a lot of attention and positive feedback. I also had a lot of messages asking if I would be doing prints, so I decided to start this crowd funder to let people pre order them. The target amount will fund the initial costs of being the prints made, having them scanned and colour matched as well as paying for the printing and postage of the prints ordered, and anything raised further than that will go towards helping me create more work which you will be able to enjoy. The crowd funder prices are cheaper than they will be afterwards, as a thank you for supporting me and my work.

Information about ordering

I'm offering high quality limited edition prints on specialist Hanemüle museum etch paper, as well as standard quality ones which are unlimited, both of which will be archival quality giclee prints produced at an independent printers here in Bristol, as well as sets of post cards. The paintings are 10x12 inches and both print options will be actual size (apart from post cards) with a border, and will be delivered unframed.

There are six paintings altogether and they are all shown here, when you've contributed please comment the number shown next to the print/s you want!

All prices include postage, with all orders outside of the uk costing a flat £5 more for the extra postage costs. Please make sure you pick the right reward for your location! Orders will be sent by November 1st, which means they should arrive in time for Christmas, and will sent by recorded and signed for delivery.

Thanks a lot for reading, and please share with anyone you think might be interested!

Lots of love xx


Here is a break down of the rewards:

Prices include postage within the UK, add £6 per order for international shipping


Set of six postcards - £10

Two sets of six postcards (12 total) - £15


Standard quality prints

1 print - £20

2 prints - £35

3 prints - £50

6 prints - £90


Limited edition high quality prints

1 print - £30

2 prints - £55

3 prints - £80

6 prints - £150

story:
Short Bio

My name is Dominic Valencia, and I am an art student at the University of Arizona. I am pursuing a degree in Studio Art with a painting and printmaking emphasis. I have the opportunity to travel to Orvieto, Italy this summer to continue my artistic studies through a university-led study abroad program, and I am so excited to be able to create art while exploring a country with such a rich artistic history. 

I am incredibly invested in my own education, and I believe that I should seize all opportunities to expand it. Creating art is my passion, and it relies so much on personal experience, critical thought, and original expression. 

This trip will be academic and educational, will help me to continually improve and hone my artistic skill and concept, and will be life changing. Thank you for your support!

Costs 

The total cost for this trip will be roughly $9000, broken down into the following categories:

$5580 - Program cost covering tuition, housing fees, health insurance, and field trips

$750 - Meals

$100 - Books/Art Supplies and Materials

$1600 - Transportation (International and Local)

$1000 - Misc. costs

Fortunately, I have been able to cover approximately half of the total cost ($4500) using academic based scholarships and grants, leaving roughly $4500 to fully fund my expedition. 

Your support will directly fund the program cost, therefore helping me pay my class tuition, housing fees, health insurance abroad, art supplies and books, and academic field trips to visit historically significant sites while on the trip. 

Any and all donations will be greatly appreciated and will help me get closer to the full amount! Thank you!

Perks 

To fully express my gratitude to every single person who supports my endeavor, I have created a full array of great perks that you will receive upon your donation. 

These include letters, postcards, signed posters, original signed and numbered limited edition intaglio prints, and original paintings. The details of these perks are listed on the right side of the page along with the dollar amount they correspond to. 

Providing artwork is the least I can do to thank you for supporting me, and I hope you enjoy it! I do not have pictures of the specific prints or paintings you will receive, however, if you would like to view some of my work, I have provided some photos on the "Gallery" tab of this page. 

If you are unable to donate, but would still like to support my academic and artistic expedition, please share this page on your social media accounts, and help me gain exposure! I appreciate it! 

Thank You!

I have travelled abroad on academic trips before, and they are some of the most rewarding and significant experiences possible. This will be the first time I can create art and work in my field abroad, and I know it will be even more valuable of an experience because of that. Your support is incredibly important, and I will be forever thankful for all donations. 

My Sincere Appreciation,

Dominic

story:
* Una traducción en Español seguirá esto párrafos y presupuesto..............

The Pierce Street Memorial Mural Project "Word Dealers" in honor of four great past Puerto Rican poets, Julia de Burgos, Pedro Pietri, David Hernández and Salima Rivera, this project is in need of your support,

Hello/Hola  I am Gamaliel Ramirez an artist/muralist, I was born in the Bronx, of NY City, a Nuyorican who has worked in Chicago as an artist/teaching artists for over 40 years now living in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and working in between San Juan, Puerto Rico and Chicago, IL. On my web site: http://gamalielramirez.weebly.com I have posted my Paintings of the 60's, 70's, 80's, 90's and of my more recent works, I have also included my Murals as well as my Resume, Exhibition Record, Artist Statement and more. To see a 10 min video of my murals go to: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhUy2ZwQ-ho. To contact my by cell call 787.306.6830 or by e-mail at: gamalielramirez@ymail.com 

The Pierce Street Memorial Mural Project location: 3501 W. Pierce Chicago, Illinois 60651-2212

This mural to be painted in the heart of Chicago's Puerto Rican community, a community plagued by problems like, high unemployment, soaring high-school dropout rates and intensive gang violence. 

Our project will serves three purposes, first this mural will educate the youth in the West Humboldt Park as well as the Chicago's greater community at large, second the project will give recognition to these renown poets that took pen to paper to share their cultural experiences, struggles and triumphs, and finally we anticipate that the mural will inspire and motivate potentially talented youth in our community to get involved in the literary arts arena (in the cultural arts industry) as opposed to dealing drugs on the street corner that perpetuates all of the above problems that have been plaguing our Community for years. 

Once the mural is created and dedicated, the mural will serve as a springboard and the location will be used to inspire a variety of cultural arts programs that can include monthly outdoor summer Poetry readings free to the public, and a variety of scheduled literary and art structured workshops designed to continue to engage the community members to take part in these positive arts activity in their community. 

All of these poets except for Julia de Burgos who was from the generation before me (February 17, 1914 – July 6, 1953), were very very dear friends of mine, they were part of my extended family, so this project is very important to me and to many of my fellow Chicago's artists friends, may they rest in peace. 

The mural title "Word Dealer's" comes from a poem of one of our beloved Chicago's poet David Hernandez, before his passing he explained this poem, "I wrote this poem as an arts economic development plan, the idea is that if we can get the street dealers to deal words/poetry instead of dealing drugs this conversion will improve our community's quality of life. Any contributions you can make to bring this project to reality will be greatly appreciated by the members as well as the community. Monetary donations can be made here on indiegogo or sent to: PIERCE Memorial Mural, 3501 W. Pierce Chicago, Illinois 60651-2212 to be deposited at U.S. Bank Account, Pierce Memorial Mural, The routing number is 071904779, The account number is 199376138897.

Mural Project Budget

Las Pierce Street Memorial Mural Project "Word Dealer's" en honor a cuatro grandes poetas puertorriqueños últimos, Julia de Burgos, Pedro Pietri, David Hernández y Salima Rivera, este proyecto está en la necesidad de su ayuda,

Hola Soy Gamaliel Ramírez un artista / muralista, naci en el Bronx, de Nueva York City, un Nuyorican que ha trabajado en Chicago como artista artista / enseñanza durante más de 40 años que viven en San Juan, Puerto Rico, y de trabajo entre San Juan, Puerto Rico y Chicago, IL. En mi sitio web: http://gamalielramirez.weebly.com he publicado mis pinturas de los años 60, 70, 80, 90 y de mis trabajos más recientes, también he incluido mis murales, así como mi curriculum vitae, Exhibición de grabación, Declaración del artista y más. Para ver un video de 10 minutos de mis murales vaya a: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhUy2ZwQ-ho.

The Pierce Street Memorial Mural Project location: 3501 W. Pierce Chicago, Illinois 60651-2212

Este mural se va a pintar en el corazón de la comunidad puertorriqueña de Chicago, una comunidad plagada de problemas como, el alto desempleo, aumento de las tasas de deserción escolar y la violencia de bandas intensiva.

Nuestra voluntad proyecto tiene tres propósitos, en primer lugar este mural será educar a los jóvenes en el Humboldt Park West, así como una mayor comunidad de Chicago en general, en segundo lugar el proyecto dará reconocimiento a estos poetas de renombre que tuvieron la pluma al papel para compartir sus experiencias culturales, luchas y triunfos, y, finalmente, podemos anticipar que el mural será inspirar y motivar a los jóvenes potencialmente talento en nuestra comunidad a involucrarse en el campo de las artes literarias (en el sector de las artes culturales) en lugar de tratar las drogas en la esquina de la calle que perpetúa la totalidad de la por encima de los problemas que han estado plagando nuestra Comunidad durante años.

Una vez que se crea y se dedicó el mural, el mural servirá como punto de partida y el lugar será utilizado para inspirar una variedad de programas de artes culturales que pueden incluir lecturas de poesía al aire libre de verano mensuales gratuitas para el público, y una variedad de arte literaria y programada talleres estructurados diseñados para que siga manteniendo los miembros de la comunidad a participar en estas actividades artísticas positiva en su comunidad.

Todos estos poetas a excepción de que era de la generación anterior a mí Julia de Burgos (17 febrero 1914 hasta 6 julio 1953), eran muy, muy queridos amigos míos, que eran parte de mi familia, por lo que este proyecto es muy importante para mí y para muchos de mis compañeros artistas amigos de Chicago, que descansen en paz.

El título mural "Word Dealer's" proviene de un poema de uno de nuestro querido de Chicago poeta David Hernández, antes de su fallecimiento, explicó este poema, "Escribí este poema como un plan de desarrollo económico artes, la idea es que si podemos conseguir la distribuidores de calle para hacer frente palabras / poesía en lugar de vender drogas esta conversión mejorará la calidad de nuestra comunidad de la vida. Cualquier contribución que pueden hacer para llevar este proyecto a la realidad será muy apreciado por los miembros, así como a la comunidad. las donaciones monetarias pueden hacerse aquí en IndieGoGo o enviados a: PIERCE Memorial Mural, 3501 W. Pierce Chicago, Illinois 60651- 2212 a depositarán en la cuenta bancaria de EE.UU., Pierce Memorial Mural, El número de ruta es 071904779, El número de cuenta es 199376138897.
story_txt:
* Una traducción en Español seguirá esto párrafos y presupuesto..............
The Pierce Street Memorial Mural Project "Word Dealers" in honor of four great past Puerto Rican poets, Julia de Burgos, Pedro Pietri, David Hernández and Salima Rivera, this project is in need of your support,
Hello/Hola  I am Gamaliel Ramirez an artist/muralist, I was born in the Bronx, of NY City, a Nuyorican who has worked in Chicago as an artist/teaching artists for over 40 years now living in San Juan, Puerto Rico, and working in between San Juan, Puerto Rico and Chicago, IL. On my web site: http://gamalielramirez.weebly.com I have posted my Paintings of the 60's, 70's, 80's, 90's and of my more recent works, I have also included my Murals as well as my Resume, Exhibition Record, Artist Statement and more. To see a 10 min video of my murals go to: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhUy2ZwQ-ho. To contact my by cell call 787.306.6830 or by e-mail at: gamalielramirez@ymail.com 

The Pierce Street Memorial Mural Project location: 3501 W. Pierce Chicago, Illinois 60651-2212
This mural to be painted in the heart of Chicago's Puerto Rican community, a community plagued by problems like, high unemployment, soaring high-school dropout rates and intensive gang violence. 


Our project will serves three purposes, first this mural will educate the youth in the West Humboldt Park as well as the Chicago's greater community at large, second the project will give recognition to these renown poets that took pen to paper to share their cultural experiences, struggles and triumphs, and finally we anticipate that the mural will inspire and motivate potentially talented youth in our community to get involved in the literary arts arena (in the cultural arts industry) as opposed to dealing drugs on the street corner that perpetuates all of the above problems that have been plaguing our Community for years. 

Once the mural is created and dedicated, the mural will serve as a springboard and the location will be used to inspire a variety of cultural arts programs that can include monthly outdoor summer Poetry readings free to the public, and a variety of scheduled literary and art structured workshops designed to continue to engage the community members to take part in these positive arts activity in their community. 
All of these poets except for Julia de Burgos who was from the generation before me (February 17, 1914 – July 6, 1953), were very very dear friends of mine, they were part of my extended family, so this project is very important to me and to many of my fellow Chicago's artists friends, may they rest in peace. 




The mural title "Word Dealer's" comes from a poem of one of our beloved Chicago's poet David Hernandez, before his passing he explained this poem, "I wrote this poem as an arts economic development plan, the idea is that if we can get the street dealers to deal words/poetry instead of dealing drugs this conversion will improve our community's quality of life. Any contributions you can make to bring this project to reality will be greatly appreciated by the members as well as the community. Monetary donations can be made here on indiegogo or sent to: PIERCE Memorial Mural, 3501 W. Pierce Chicago, Illinois 60651-2212 to be deposited at U.S. Bank Account, Pierce Memorial Mural, The  routing number is 071904779, The account number is 199376138897.

story:
In two weeks, I’m running a 10k. This began as a personal goal over the summer.

As admirable as personal fitness goals are, I’ve realized in recent weeks that most of my personal goals (running a 10k, graduating from university, getting into grad school) are luxuries. My basic daily needs are more than filled, and so I can worry about my workload, my extracurricular responsibilities, my personal health. 

And so, a few weeks ago, I decided I wasn’t just running for me anymore.

Media coverage of the Syrian refugee crisis has fluctuated, but the numbers have remained staggering- 4 million refugees, 7.5 million internally displaced. In Lebanon, 1 in 5 people are refugees (mostly Syrians, some Iraqis). The UN and the usual crisis response parties are ill-equipped to handle both the amount of people and the length of the crisis (civil war broke out in 2011). 

I’m launching this campaign to sponsor my 10k in two weeks to raise money for the Canadian Foodgrains Bank, who are working on the ground in Lebanon, Jordan and Syria (http://foodgrainsbank.ca/campaigns/syria/) to provide food relief. More broadly than their relief work, their organization is an ecumenical response to food justice issues around the world, so I’m excited to partner with them for this project.

For more detail on my motivation and passion for this project, check out my blog post here - https://thebarefootscholar.wordpress.com/2015/09/29/ill-walk-through-hell-with-you/

The Details

The goal is set at $500 ($50 per kilometre), but hopefully we can do better! Every little bit counts

The money raised will be collected by me and sent to the Canadian Foodgrains Bank by cheque, designated for Syria crisis relief. If you would like a tax receipt, either donate directly through CFB (http://foodgrainsbank.ca/donate-now/) or talk to me (and I might be able to sort something out my contacts in the organization).

The Impact

For more details about the Foodgrains Bank work on the ground - http://foodgrainsbank.ca/campaigns/syria/

In Lebanon, they're providing food vouchers to 5800 refugees. 

In Syria, they provide monthly food boxes to 17,500 families and 3,500 displaced families. 

In Jordan, they provide food for 500 families per month. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate directly to my campaign, please share this with your friends and consider ways that you can launch similar campaigns in your own communities. 

As Elrond says in one of my favourite Tolkien quotes, "Such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere."

story:
There are many news blogs and reports of the art world on the Web (artinfo, hyperallergic, artsy, artdailynewsletter, and so on), but none aimed at helping would-be and working artists navigate the thickets of a professional life. And none of the extant sites takes advantage of the interactivity of the Internet to provide information, news, and even entertainment.

The art world has exploded in recent years, but art-related sites have scarcely kept pace with the possibilities for communication and idea sharing (what we get instead are overlapping reports on the same artists, the same art fairs, the same auctions, and the same biennials and museum shows).

Vasari21, named for the great Renaissance chronicler and our present century, will offer straightforward reports, video and audio interviews, interactive forums, and visuals of interest to artists and art professionals. 


Podcasts ​

Interviews with critics, curators, dealers, and other artists will give career advice, historical perspectives, and anecdotes about a life in art. Some examples:

*Peter Plagens on his career as an artist and critic

*Petah Coyne on surviving the art-fair mania

*Ellen Harvey on her life as a "conceptual realist"

*Individual artists on the quality of residencies worldwide (such as, Elisabeth Condon on a Swatch fellowship in Shanghai; Karen Giusti on the Bogliasco Foundation in Genoa)

*Tony Oursler on building a career as a video artist

*Irene Hofmann, director of Site Santa Fe, on biennial fatigue

*Amei Wallach on making the transition from art critic to filmmaker

*Kay Larson on the John Cage influence

*Cultural historian Arden Reed on “slow looking”

*Art dealer and scholar Francis Naumann on his years with Marcel Duchamp

*Critic Blake Gopnik on writing the official biography of Andy Warhol

*Yancey Richardson on her life as a photo dealer

*Nancy Princenthal on finding Agnes Martin

*Mona Kuhn on photographing the nude

*Graham NIckson, artist and dean of the New York Studio School, on the enduring importance of learning to draw

*Art historian William Wallace on life with Michelangelo

*Eric Fischl on writing his autobiography

*Christopher Benson on realist painting today

*Frank Stella on the occasion of his retrospective at the Whitney

*Kathy Butterly on ceramics 

*Painter Deborah Brown on the art scene in Bushwick

*Individual curators--like Laura Hoptman at the Museum of Modern Art,Tricia Paik at the Indianapolis Museum of Art, and Liz Armstrong of the Palm Springs Art Museum--on getting museum attention

*Rob Storr, dean of the graduate program at Yale, on what’s so special about the curriculum

*Photographer David Leaser on launching his successful photography career at the Architectural Digest home fair (yes, that’s right, a home-furnishings show)

*Scholar and curator Joachim Pissarro on the real van Gogh

*RoseLee Goldberg on performance art today

In time, as the site and staff grow, I envision doing studio interviews via video, which will give an inside look at the day-to-day life of an artist.

Interactive Forums​

A “community forum” will allow artists to seek out advice and connect around the globe ("Help, my dealer just closed his doors and made off with five of my paintings! What should I do?" “Where can I learn about painting on copper?” “What does it mean when my best collector starts selling off my work?” “Where can I get tax advice for artists?”). 


Articles and Essays

The site will feature a regularly changing roster of straightforward reporting and self-help not covered by other venues, on topics such as

*Married to an artist: Janine Antoni and Paul Ramirez Jonas, Janet Cardiff and George Bures-Miller, April Gornik and Eric Fischl, Alison Berry and Julian Hatton, Leslie Wayne and Don Porcaro and other art couples talk about living and sharing the creative life

*From gallerinas to art handlers to curators and museum directors, who makes how much in the art world?

*What is the value of an MFA, and which are the most useful?

*Do you believe in muses?

*How to have a career outside New York City

*What do critics look for in new and emerging artists?

*How to use Facebook and other social media to enhance your career

*The psychology of pricing; how art dealers use it

*Crowd-sourcing for artists

*What makes for a successful website, according to dealers and collectors

*How important are reviews? Do artists heed the censure or suggestions of critics?

*Artists on the “aha” moment

*Artists' consultants and publicists: What you need to know

*Gallery contracts: Should you have one? What should it include?

*Common scams to which you can fall prey



YOU Tell Me What To Do

This is a site where readers can help determine the content: Do you have a subject you’d like to see addressed and reported? Just let me know.

Vasari21 will also spotlight new books and artists often overlooked by the mainstream press (“Under the Radar”); a regular feature called "Did You Know?" will present art-historical factoids, often linked to museum shows, of interest to a wide audience (for instance, “Who was the real Mme Cézanne?”); and "Links We Love" will present stories you may have missed in the mainstream press. A weekly video contest for "Stupid Artist Tricks" will offer some light-hearted and offbeat moments from the creative life.


About Me--Radio Interviews and Article Links

As a journalist with 20 years' experience writing about art for ARTnews, The Wall Street Journal, and other publications, I am in a privileged position to launch a site dedicated to this sector of the art world. I have further experience as a radio talk-show host and for a year ran a successful website for women called WiredBerries. More about me can be found here, in an interview with Brainard Carey of Yale University Radio: http://museumofnonvisibleart.com/interviews/ann...

A background in art history (degrees from Princeton and Columbia universities) has given me a solid foundation from which to talk to critics, curators, and other art professionals. I have written hundreds of reviews, scores of profiles, and have probably interviewed more than 500 artists in the course of my career. One of the more popular stories ever published in ARTnews was my piece on the ins-and-outs of studio visits: http://www.artnews.com/2013/09/30/a-guide-to-do...

Another favorite was about artists’ early influences: http://www.artnews.com/2014/05/27/the-art-that-made-artists-artists/

If you would like to read more of my work, simply Google “Ann Landi ARTnews” or “Ann Landi Wall Street Journal.”


My goal is to raise $24,000 to launch the site and underwrite its first year. And your donations reap rewards:

$20 gets you a one-year subscription

$35 a two-year subscription, or one year plus a free gift subscription

$50 a two-year subscription plus the Vasari21 apron-smock

$100 a lifetime subscription to the site, plus the Vasari apron-smock and a copy of Giorgio Vasari's "Lives of the Artists"

$250 a lifetime subscription, plus the Vasari21 apron-smock, "The Lives of the Artists," and a DVD of Simon Schama's "The Power of Art"

$501-$999 a lifetime subscription to Vasari21.com, plus all of the above and an original print from Paul Pascarella (www.paulpascarella.com).

$1000 a lifetime subscription to Vasari21.com, Giorgio Vasari's "Lives of the Artists," Simon Schama's "The Power of Art," a Paul Pascarella print, and a DVD of a stand-up art history lecture by Ann Landi on“The Artist’s Studio from Velàzquez to von Rydingsvard” 

A launch date is projected for mid-November, 2015. Each subscriber will be emailed a password and easy instructions to access the site before the launch.


Photo Credits for the Video

Ann Waldman and Pat Steir in front of a Steir painting at Cheim & Read, New York. Photo by Lauren Greenberg (maepoe.blogspot.com).

El Anatsui at his studio in Nigeria, 2010 ©El Anatsui.  Photo by Jodi Bieber.  Courtesy of the artist and Jack Shainman Gallery, New York.

Louise Bourgeois.  Courtesy of Cheim & Read, New York.

Lynda Benglis. Courtesy of Cheim & Read, New York.

Nick Cave in studio, 2012 ©Nick Cave.  Photo by James Prinz Photography.  Courtesy of the artist and Jack Shainman Gallery, New York.

Nari Ward. Courtesy the artist and Lehmann Maupin, New York and Hong Kong

of Modern Art,Tricia Paik at the Indianapolis Museum of Art, and Liz Armstrong of the Palm Springs Art Museum--on getting
museum attention
*Rob Storr, dean of the graduate program at Yale, on
what’s so special about the curriculum
*Photographer David Leaser on launching his successful
photography career at the Architectural
Digest home fair (yes, that’s right, a home-furnishings show)*Scholar and curator Joachim Pissarro on the real van Gogh*RoseLee Goldberg on performance art today

In time, as the site and staff grow, I envision doing
studio interviews via video, which will give an inside look at the day-to-day life of an
artist.
Interactive Forums​
A “community forum” will
allow artists to seek out advice and connect around the globe ("Help, my
dealer just closed his doors and made off with five of my paintings! What
should I do?" “Where can I learn about painting on copper?” “What does it
mean when my best collector starts selling off my work?” “Where can I get tax advice
for artists?”). 
Articles and Essays

The site will feature a
regularly changing roster of straightforward reporting and self-help not
covered by other venues, on topics such as
*Married to an artist: Janine Antoni and Paul Ramirez Jonas, Janet Cardiff and George Bures-Miller, April Gornik and Eric Fischl, Alison Berry and Julian Hatton, Leslie Wayne and Don Porcaro and other art couples talk about living and sharing the creative life
*From
gallerinas to art handlers to curators and museum directors, who makes how much
in the art world?
*What
is the value of an MFA, and which are the most useful? 
*Do
you believe in muses?
*How
to have a career outside New York City
*What
do critics look for in new and emerging artists?
*How
to use Facebook and other social media to enhance your career
*The
psychology of pricing; how art dealers use it*Crowd-sourcing for artists
*What
makes for a successful website, according to dealers and collectors
*How
important are reviews? Do artists heed the censure or suggestions of critics?
*Artists
on the “aha” moment*Artists' consultants and publicists: What you need to know*Gallery contracts: Should you have one? What should it include?*Common scams to which you can fall prey
YOU Tell Me What To Do
This is a site where readers
can help determine the content: Do you have a subject you’d like to see addressed and reported? Just let me know.
Vasari21 will also spotlight
new books and artists often overlooked by the mainstream press (“Under the
Radar”); a regular feature called "Did You Know?" will present
art-historical factoids, often linked to museum shows, of interest to a wide
audience (for instance, “Who was the real Mme Cézanne?”); and "Links We Love" will present stories you may have missed in the mainstream press. A weekly video contest for "Stupid Artist Tricks" will offer some light-hearted and offbeat moments from the creative life.
About Me--Radio Interviews and Article LinksAs a journalist with 20
years' experience writing about art for ARTnews,
The Wall Street Journal, and other
publications, I am in a privileged position to launch a site dedicated to this
sector of the art world. I have further experience as a radio talk-show host
and for a year ran a successful website for women called WiredBerries. More
about me can be found here, in an interview with Brainard Carey of Yale
University Radio: http://museumofnonvisibleart.com/interviews/ann...
A background in art history (degrees from Princeton and Columbia universities) has given me a solid foundation from which to talk to critics, curators, and other art professionals. I have written hundreds of reviews,
scores of profiles, and have probably interviewed more than 500 artists in the
course of my career. One of the more popular stories ever published in ARTnews was my piece on the ins-and-outs
of studio visits: http://www.artnews.com/2013/09/30/a-guide-to-do...
Another favorite was about
artists’ early influences: http://www.artnews.com/2014/05/27/the-art-that-made-artists-artists/
If you would like to read
more of my work, simply Google “Ann Landi ARTnews” or “Ann Landi Wall Street
Journal.”
My goal is to raise $24,000 to launch the site and underwrite its
first year. And your donations reap rewards:
$20 gets
you a one-year subscription
$35 a
two-year subscription, or one year plus a free gift subscription
$50 a two-year subscription plus the Vasari21 apron-smock$100 a lifetime subscription to the site, plus the Vasari apron-smock and a copy of Giorgio Vasari's "Lives of the Artists"$250 a lifetime subscription, plus the Vasari21 apron-smock, "The Lives of the Artists," and a DVD of Simon Schama's "The Power of Art"
$501-$999 a lifetime subscription to Vasari21.com, plus all of the above and an original print from Paul Pascarella (www.paulpascarella.com).
$1000 a lifetime subscription to Vasari21.com, Giorgio Vasari's "Lives of the Artists," Simon Schama's "The Power of Art," a Paul Pascarella print, and a DVD of a stand-up art history lecture by Ann Landi on“The Artist’s Studio from Velàzquez to von Rydingsvard” 
A launch
date is projected for mid-November, 2015. Each subscriber will be emailed a
password and easy instructions to access the site before the launch.Photo Credits for the VideoAnn Waldman and Pat Steir in front of a Steir painting at Cheim & Read, New York. Photo by Lauren Greenberg (maepoe.blogspot.com).
El
Anatsui at his studio in Nigeria, 2010 ©El
Anatsui.  Photo by Jodi Bieber.  Courtesy of the artist and
Jack Shainman Gallery, New York.


Louise Bourgeois.  Courtesy of Cheim & Read, New York.Lynda Benglis. Courtesy of Cheim & Read, New York.


Nick Cave in
studio, 2012 ©Nick Cave. 
Photo by James Prinz Photography.  Courtesy of the artist and
Jack Shainman Gallery, New York.


Nari Ward.
Courtesy the artist and Lehmann Maupin, New York and Hong Kong

story:
Short Summary

I'm a country girl, an entrepreneur, and an artist who would like to share the best of what southern burners have to offer.

The Chariot of Dreams takes off when we challenge the dreams that don’t serve us and step away from the scripts we've been given about how be good, safe and righteous.  This challenge is a journey every person shares.  The Chariot provides sanctuary for travelers on this journey!

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $11,500:

  • $3000 for the tractor
  • $1500 for metal
  • $1500 for generator
  • $150 for fuel
  • $600 for light and décor
  • $1500 for sound system
  • $3000 for our 2500 miles journey from the Southeastern US to the playa.
  • $400 for food, ice, water, and sweet tea
  • The wood, mattresses, and curtains have all be free-cycled.

Donor Perks:

  • $15 - A custom sticker from our inaugural year on the playa and a thank you!
  • $50 - Nightmare and the Chariot of Dreams heart shaped laser cut wood pendant, a sticker, and a thank you!
  • $100 - One of a kind, signed, painted, and numbered 8 inch melted metal heart, a sticker, and a thank you.
  • $250 - One of a kind, signed, painted, and numbered 12 inch melted metal heart with wings, a sticker, and a thank you. 
  • $500 - 24 inch metal sculpture silhouette of the Pegasus Tractor (with lights!), a sticker, and a thank you.

Our goal is to give each contributor an original piece of the project.  What better way than with a one of a kind piece of art.  The ultimate token of our love and gratitude for our supporters!

We have worked hard and come so far with blood, sweat and tears!  Our journey isn't over and we need your support!  Join us to offer love, sanctuary and new friendship on the playa.
