-L’APE SPEZIALE officina artigianale di saponi naturali e affini. Via Santuario di Oropa 107 a Biella

http://www.apespeziale.it/

https://www.facebook.com/pages/LApe-Speziale-Officina-Artigianale-Saponi-Naturali-e-Affini/391061364303002?ref=stream

-OFF ART di Pamela Venturi. Ceramica artigianale. Contrada del Carmine 5 , Brescia

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Off-Art/205530209586811
http://www.pamelaventuri.com/

I go by the name Saint Hoax and I am a Middle Eastern POPlitical artist. 

Just to be clear, the country listed above is not actually the place that I currently reside in (I Just had to fill that), but I am living in the Middle East. 

I am trying to remain anonymous for the time being due to the fact that my art is considered offensive in many parts of my surrounding region. Yes, as hard as it is to believe, in 2014 people can still be highly offended by someone's opinion. In fact, I've received a significant amount of threats and negative messages deterring me from going forward with my art project. As much as I would love to sign my work with my real name and express myself more freely, I simply can't do that for security reasons. 

Ever since I was a child I always dreamt of being a painter. I was lucky enough to be born with some sort of talent and even luckier to have a supportive family that provided me with the means to pursue a degree in art and design. I then developed a certain interest in using my art skills as a platform to criticize politics. 

"War Drags You Out"

I began working on W.D.Y.O last June but sadly enough my artwork was not well received here in the Middle East. Almost all the galleries, art curators, and potential investors refused to take part in my project, labeling it as "offensive and disgraceful".

I have been living in an endless war that has taken its toll on the Middle East and everyone that is part of this region. No one has the time or the means to invest in or appreciate art at the moment. I was being forced to get real, but I was not ready to do that. As a last resort I reached out to international sources. The W.D.Y.O series was immediately featured on various blogs and received a lot of attention.

Huffington Post, Buzz Feed, Jezebel, Trend Hunter, CBC News and many more were among the blogs that supported the project, and for that I am grateful. 

But it is time to carry the project even further, and to do so I have to move it outside the Middle East. I am trying to rent out a pop up space in New York where I can display and sell my art for a certain period of time. New york has always been the citadel of art and design. The first time I visited New york I just knew I had to be part of it one day. That big apple stole my heart ever since. 

Anything you can offer will be of great help. Whether it's a Dollar or the entire amount, I will be forever grateful. You can also help by sharing this campaign.

This is where your money would go:

$2,500 : Ticket + travel expenses

$8,000 : Art space rental in New York

$5,000 : Cost of temporary accommodation + living + art production

$500: Printing Flyers + distribution for announcement. 

In total that would be $16,000. 

Anything else I can raise would help me rent out a better space and produce more art. 

I know you can't see me, and you don't know who I am. But I am just like you, a person with a dream. Don't let war drag me out.

story:
UPDATE JANUARY 5, 2014

Check out the new video: "Let's Close the Deal"

So, here’s the deal: The gallery is  finally here in the new space at 25 Railroad Street and it's fantastic! THANK YOU  for getting me this far! As you can see, the campaign has progressed well, and this campaign has generated lots of excellent contributions from artists, friends and patrons alike. People are streaming in and are loving the new gallery. It is airy, filled with light, and provides space for our artists' work to be displayed with great pride and beauty.


Now, we are seeking a final boost in the final week of our campaign, which ends Jan. 11. We still need you! For those who have not yet contributed, please consider joining this extraordinary community effort on behalf of art, artists and small business. For those who have generously contributed, thank you. If you are inspired and able, please consider a final contribution.  

Obviously this was a very ambitious goal for a very ambitious project. I am stunned with the enthusiasm that has come with contributions large and small. If we can further close the gap by Jan. 11, this will have been a terrific success.

Good faith has been at the core of this effort: Various contractors and vendors agreed to delay being paid while the campaign has been going. Many of the gallery's artists have contributed "perks" to contributors at various levels, along with other heavy lifting and business support for the move.

For instance, sculptor Joe Wheaton, whose work I have carried for years, created both of the videos for the Indiegogo campaign, helped with construction and offered his gourmet chef skills as a "perk." For a $1,500 gift, one contributor will receive a gourmet homemade Thai dinner for 12, at the galley, prepared by Wheaton. The dinner was among the first "perks" to go!

"Part of what makes this, the Berkshires, a great community is that people are willing to take risks," said Wheaton. "Lauren's risk is going to benefit me and a lot of other hard-working artists who already now have much better exposure. And the community will benefit from this wonderful new gallery."

It's not over yet: While we are up and running, we have relocation costs to pay, and with your final push, we can get closer to the ultimate goal.

In the meantime, come in, have a look, say hi. Tell your friends we’re here at 25 Railroad Street in Great Barrington, selling great art and providing top-notch fine art framing services.


Let's Move the Gallery

I am Lauren  Clark, owner of Lauren Clark Fine Art, a successful gallery and frame shop in the lovely village of Housatonic, Massachusetts. In my 21 years as a gallery owner and framing expert, I have devoted my professional life to representing the work of hundreds of talented international and regional artists. I have framed thousands of paintings, photographs and other work for artists and art clients. I am a professional paper marbler of more than 30 years, with substantial success in this field. I have enjoyed what every business owner longs for: dedicated, loyal and supportive clientele who keep coming back.

I am so proud of the business I have built and grateful to the artists and clients who choose to work with me. They are my inspiration every day, and I am now poised to celebrate their work in bigger and better ways.

THE CHALLENGE! THE GOAL!

The bright blue Park Street building where I have leased my gallery is being sold. I must move my entire operation and the work of my gifted artists and crafts professionals--among them Bart Arnold, Daniel Bellow, Richard Britell, Julio Granda, Liz Kinder, Geoffrey Moss, Terry Wise, and Joe Wheaton, to name a few.

The good news: I have secured a new, 3,000-square-foot space at 25 Railroad Street in nearby downtown Great Barrington, the old Gatsby's. Great Barrington is a true hot spot, featured recently in an MSNBC news profile and named THE top small town in the U.S. by Smithsonian Magazine. I have been able to establish a modest presence already in my new space on Railroad Street, to take advantage of the holiday season while closing my old gallery. But there remains much work to be done at significant expense, and several contractors have agreed to await compensation while this campaign takes place. For their trust, confidence and community spirit, I am so very grateful!

Even better news: In support of "Let's Move the Gallery" many of my loyal gallery artists are enthusiastically contributing "incentive art" as perks to contributors at various levels. From a Richard Britell original painting to pottery by Daniel Bellow and gallery evening dinner for 12 by chef-artist Joe Wheaton and art cards by Ann Getsinger -- along with many others -- these perks will delight you. Please take a look at what they have to offer!

You can help: Friends, neighbors, clients, other artists, business colleagues and others who are willing to pitch in to help offset the relocation costs and boost the future of Lauren Clark Fine Art and its artists. There's hardly a donation level that doesn't include an art perk: check it out!

My immediate costs include:

  •   Construction, lighting, painting and infrastructure improvements at the new location
  •   Moving costs and technology updates
  •   Advertising and marketing to support the launch at the new location

It's my deepest wish that this campaign be NOT just about Lauren Clark Fine Art, but about its artists and their exceptional work. They are deserving of top-notch representation not just in their gallery owner, but in the gallery itself, and as we know, location means so much.

Several remarkable people who have worked to help me launch the "Let's Move the Gallery Campaign" and I would like to recognize them and encourage any of you to connect with them professionally:

  • Joe Wheaton: artist, videography, and site preparation
  • Ellen Lahr, EGLahr Communications: marketing and PR support
  • Richard Britell: artist, construction and painting
  • Dianne Steele: web support at all levels
  • Dolores Curto: marketing, window design, and enthusiasm
  • Scott Clark: video music, painting, brotherly love and pie!
  • Franco Pellegrino: artist and painting and painting and painting...

Thank you in advance for your support and community spirit. Please make sure to stop by our new downtown location on Railroad Street in Great Barrington.


THE PERKS

The Ultimate Perk:  "Tuscany" by Richard Britell, oil on canvas, 30" x 60" 


Ann Getsinger: One of 15 Different Postcards  SOLD OUT!


Lauren Clark: Marbleized Paper 


Berkshire Mountain Bakery  SOLD OUT!



Daniel Bellow: Porcelain Wine Cups


Potter Extraordinaire, Daniel Bellow


Daniel Bellow: Porcelain Mugs

Shell Chic Book


Gift Certificate from Castle Street Cafe



Ellen Boll-Brown: One of Five Original Mixed-Media Drawings

"Lovely Companions," watercolor and pastel on paper, 5" x 7"


"Woodland Bunny," pastel on paper, 7" x 5"  SOLD OUT!


"The Secret Garden," watercolor and pastel on paper, 7" x 9"  SOLD OUT!


"On the Porch Together." watercolor and pastel on paper, 8" x 6"


"Sunflower," watercolor and pastel on paper, 8" x 10"


Richard Britell: One of Four Prints

"Apple Tree,"  14 1/4" x 5 3/4"


"The Met," 9" x 7 3/4"


"Black Suffragette," 11 1/4" x 4 1/4"


"Harlem Tenement," 7 5/8" x 14 1/4"


Sharon Wandel: Gorgeous, Elegant Silver Bracelet


David Boag: Cement Garden Leaves


Bart Arnold: "Berlin Bookstore," giclee print, 9" x 12  SOLD OUT!


Beki Killorin: One of Four Limited Edition etchings:

"Insight," hand-colored etching, 7" x 7"


"Flutter,"  hand-colored etching, 7" x 7"


"Overseer," hand-colored etching, 7" x 7"


"Red Preener," hand-colored etching, 7" x 7"


Terry Wise: One of Five Collages

"Capricious," collage on board,     6" x  12"


"Abode," collage on board,  8" x 10"


"Bounteous," collage on board,     8" x 10"


"Abstract," collage on board,     8" x 10"


"Atelier," collage on board,  6" x 12"


Blown Glass Vase by Viscosity Glass, approximately 12" x 7" x 7"


Blown Glass Vase by Hanson and Kastles, approximately 16" x 5" x 5"


Richard Britell, "Portrait of Paul Gauguin," acrylic on zinc plated steel, 5 3/4" x 5 1/2"


Franco Pellegrino, "Golden Orchard,"  watercolor, 18" x 22", framed


Julio Granda, "Spatial Genesis III," pastel, 24" x 16"


Ann Getsinger: "Rind,"  oil on rag panel, 10" x 8", framed


Bart Arnold: "Tabula Rasa,"  wall sculpture-acrylic on wood, 18" x 14" x 4"

Sculptor, Joe Wheaton, lounging on one of his sculptures


Artist and Chef Joe Wheaton tantalizes your tastebuds!       SOLD OUT!


T.L. Lange, untitled, mixed media on paper, 35" x 30"


About Lauren Clark

PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE

LAUREN CLARK FINE ART, Housatonic, MA

OWNER/DIRECTOR/PICTURE FRAMER 

2006-Present

  • Curate all artwork and shows in the gallery including paintings, drawings, collage, fine art prints, sculpture, glass, ceramics and jewelry
  • Arrange all displays of art and craft including floral design inside and outside of the gallery
  • Design framing for artwork within the scope of the gallery 
  • Design and executes framing for private clients and designers 
  • Use self-designed marbled paper in antique frame design as required
  • Maintain relationships with artists represented, visiting studios as needed and/or through website visits, email and phone contact
  • Manage daily operations of business including ordering of all framing materials, lighting, office supplies, etc. 
  • Manage staff and interns
  • On-sight design and installation of artwork at commercial venues and private residences
  • Curate and hang shows at local establishments, including galleries, restaurants, and office spaces
  • Maintain gallery website
  • Handle advertising, marketing and bookkeeping tasks
  • Handle all shipping for artwork

TOKONOMA GALLERY, Housatonic, MA

CO-OWNER

1992-2006

  • Co-curated all artwork and shows featuring paintings, sculpture, glass, ceramics and jewelry
  • Arranged window and floor displays of art and craft 
  • Co-designed framing for artwork within the scope of the gallery
  • Primary framer designing and executing custom framing for private clients and designers 
  • Instructed business partner in framing techniques and proper use of equipment 
  • Co-managed daily operations of business with a concentration on the framing portion
  • Managed ordering of all framing materials and supplies
  • Managed staff and interns
  • Maintained relationships with artists represented, visiting studios as needed and/or through website visits, email and phone contact
  • On-sight design and installation of artwork at commercial venues and private residences
  • Curated and hung shows at local establishments including galleries and restaurants 
  • Handled shipping for artwork

NOT JUST PAPER

Armonk, NY/Great Barrington, MA/Housatonic, MA

OWNER/PAPER MARBLER 

1986-PRESENT

  • Design and create hand-marbled papers
  • Work with bookbinders, art supply stores, specialty paper stores, artists and designers
  • Teach paper marbling techniques both privately and at area institutions 
  • Sold reproduction rights to Readers Digest, Dover Publications and others

CATHERINE SYLVIA REISS

Scarsdale, NY

DESIGNER/MANAGER 

1985-1989

  • Designed and executed matting, especially “French” matting of antique prints in custom frame shop 
  • Custom framing
  • Managed frame shop, including order placement and maintaining stock 
  • Managed staff 

EDUCATION

  • Dean College

    Franklin, MA, English Major

  • Elizabeth Seton College

        Yonkers, NY, Art Major

Shows Curated:

Julio Granda, “Core Samples from Earth to the Cosmos”, 2013

Julio Granda at Castle Street Cafe, “Paintings from the Eighties”, 2013

Susie Hardcastle, “Playing in the Garden that Susie Grew”, 2013

Geoffrey Moss, “Pop Art”, 2012

Helga S. Orthofer, “Pastels”, 2012

Group Show, co-curated, “Ten Spot”, Lichtenstein Center for the Arts, Pittsfield, MA, 2012

Richard Britell, “Measuring the Universe”, 2011

Ann Getsinger, “Sky Slice & the Pedestal Series”, 2011

Bart Arnold, “Places”, 2011

Julio Granda, “silences of the land, sounds of the sea”, 2011 

Group Show, “The Paper Trail”, Lichtenstein Center for the Arts, Pittsfield, MA, 2010

Geoffrey Moss, “Inappropriate Appropriations”, 2010

Richard Britell, “And Now for Some Things Completely Different” 2010

Group Show, “The Figure, The Figure, The Figure and The Figure”, 2010

Group Show, “Small Works” 2010

Channing Lefebvre, “Associations”, 2009 

Group Show, "A nest of robins in her hair", 2009

Group Show, “Unwilted, Unprocessed, Unconventional, Four Newly Picked, Garden Fresh Artists”, 2009

Group Show, “22 Artists/Works on Paper”, 2009

Group Show, “The Salon Show”, 2008

Geoffrey Moss, “Breaking Plates and Flying Dogs”, 2008

Group Show, “5 Berkshire Painters”, 2008

Richard Britell, “NY, NY”, 2007

Tina Sotis, “New Work”, 2007

Group Show, “4 Women Standing Nude”, 2006

Tina Sotis, co-curated, “Secrets Cast Long Shadows”, 2004

Julio Granda, co-curated, “Broadsides”, Barbara Boughton Interiors, 2004

Christine Neill, co-curated, “Berkshire Summers: a retrospective”, 2003

Anthony Nordoff, co-curated, “Works on Paper”, 2003 

T.L. Lange, co-curated, “A Tribute”, 2002

Tina Sotis, co-curated, “The Solitary Muse”, 2001

Ann Getsinger, co-curated, “Rare Sightings”, 2001

Richard Britell, co-curated, From Architecture to Abstraction, 2000

Ann Getsinger, co-curated, “Oh, That the Moon Doth Glow”, 1998

Anthony Nordoff, co-curated, “Of Flowers and Dancers and Love”, 1996

Joe Barber, co-curated “A Retrospective”, 1996

From a Richard Britell original painting to pottery by Daniel Bellow and gallery evening dinner for 12 by chef-artist Joe Wheaton and art cards by Ann Getsinger -- along with many others -- these perks will delight you. Please take a look at what they have to offer!You can help: Friends, neighbors, clients, other artists, business colleagues and others who are willing to pitch in to help offset the relocation costs and boost the future of Lauren Clark Fine Art and its artists. There's hardly a donation level that doesn't include an art perk: check it out! My immediate costs include:
  Construction, lighting, painting and infrastructure improvements at the new location
  Moving costs and technology updates
  Advertising and marketing to support the launch at the new location 
It's my deepest wish that this campaign be NOT just about Lauren Clark Fine Art, but about its artists and their exceptional work. They are deserving of top-notch representation not just in their gallery owner, but in the gallery itself, and as we know, location means so much. Several remarkable people who have worked to help me launch the "Let's Move the Gallery Campaign" and I would like to recognize them and encourage any of you to connect with them professionally:
Joe Wheaton: artist, videography, and site preparation
Ellen Lahr, EGLahr Communications: marketing and PR support
Richard Britell: artist, construction and painting
Dianne Steele: web support at all levels
Dolores Curto: marketing, window design, and enthusiasm
Scott Clark: video music, painting, brotherly love and pie!
Franco Pellegrino: artist and painting and painting and painting...
Thank you in advance for your support and community spirit. Please make sure to stop by our new downtown location on Railroad Street in Great Barrington.THE PERKSThe Ultimate Perk:  "Tuscany" by Richard Britell, oil on canvas, 30" x 60" Ann Getsinger: One of story:
Short Summary

+I am a poet and educator from Chapel Hill, NC. Growing up outside the rural buffer in Councilville, I was taught that a closed mouth catches no flies; that it was best in most cases if I was seen and not heard. To the people in my life silence meant safety for a boy who’s skin would be the filter through which the world saw him. In elementary school I would find myself listening to the love poems my brother would write to the weeks crush. Immersed in the wordplay, imagery and emotion that would often be accompanied by a doodle of an angel or hearts, I fell in relationship with thought in 2verse.  In high school with the encouragement of my English teacher I would start my own journey as a poet who at that point had only been writing raps and love ballads. Awakened by the freedom I found in verse, I dedicated my life to creating spaces for young people to share their poems, stories and voices running open mics. I am blessed to have co founded an organization called the Sacrificial Poets.+I believe that you must create Art as you enjoy it. Thus, Shots Of MoonShine is a series of seven artbooks. Each of them will be an original poem illustrated by a visual artist or photographer and in some cases, a mixture of the two mediums. In all of my performing and teaching I have never published my own work. As someone who's often a perfectionist much of the hold up has been want to create something I am proud of and to work with other artists. +This will be inspiration for other young brown men I see everyday in classrooms who feel like their stories don't matter. We are a dynamic generation of MoonMen not afraid to speak truth to power!


What We Need & What You Get

$5,000 will cover

  •   New computer for formatting the works 
  •  publishing
  •  promotional as gratitude events.
  • I have been blessed to be surrounded with some of the best artists and designers in the south who have agreed to help me with this part.

  • Gifts

  • Signed prints from ShotsOfMoonShine
  • Knowledge & Understanding Mixtape
  • Signed Shots of Moonshine Accordian Book of with personal thank you
  • Shots Of Moonshine tea towels
  • Gypsy-Witch Handmade Moon Jewelry. 
  • This project will happen even if the goal is not reached. Tis too important

The Effect:

  • As a spoken word poet in a small town I am often if not always the medium for my Art. As powerful as that can be I believe true strength lies in collaboration and working together. That said, I am so ecstatic about working with artist in other mediums and lenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are not able to give a monetary donation or the web is feels risky to you. I would love for you to share the link and or contact me personally  this project is collaborative and I am sure it will evolve as I speak with more of you about it. That said, I welcome your ideas, skills and offerings concerning publishing, artist collaboration and whatever else come to mind. If you are a visual artist i would love to see your interpretation of the title of the series in whatever medium suittsyouwrite.

Growing up outside the rural buffer in Councilville, I was taught that a closed mouth catches no flies; that it was best in most cases if I was seen and not heard. To the people in my life silence meant safety for a boy who’s skin would be the filter through which the world saw him. In elementary school I would find myself listening to the love poems my brother would write to the weeks crush. Immersed in the wordplay, imagery and emotion that would often be accompanied by a doodle of an angel or hearts, I fell in relationship with thought in 2verse.  In high school with the encouragement of my English teacher I would start my own journey as a poet who at that point had only been writing raps and love ballads. Awakened by the freedom I found in verse, I dedicated my life to creating spaces for young people to share their poems, stories and voices running open mics. I am blessed to have co founded an organization called the Sacrificial Poets.+I believe that you must create Art as you enjoy it. Thus, Shots Of MoonShine is a series of seven artbooks. Each of them will be an original poem illustrated by a visual artist or photographer and in some cases, a mixture of the two mediums. In all of my performing and teaching I have never published my own work. As someone who's often a perfectionist much of the hold up has been want to create something I am proud of and to work with other artists. +This will be inspiration for other young brown men I see everyday in classrooms who feel like their stories don't matter. We are a dynamic generation of MoonMen not afraid to speak truth to power!



What We Need & What You Get
$5,000 will cover 


  New computer for formatting the works 
 publishing 

 promotional as gratitude events. 

I have been blessed to be surrounded with some of the best artists and designers in the south who have agreed to help me with this part. 

 Gifts
Signed prints from ShotsOfMoonShine 

Knowledge & Understanding Mixtape

Signed Shots of Moonshine Accordian Book of with personal thank you
Shots Of Moonshine tea towels

Gypsy-Witch Handmade Moon Jewelry. 
This project will happen even if the goal is not reached. Tis too important 



 The Effect:


As a spoken word poet in a small town I am often if not always the medium for my Art. As powerful as that can be I believe true strength lies in collaboration and working together. That said, I am so ecstatic about working with artist in other mediums and lenses. 



Other Ways You Can Help
If you are not able to give a monetary donation or the web is feels risky to you. I would love for you to share the link and or contact me personally  this project is collaborative and I am sure it will evolve as I speak with more of you about it. That said, I welcome your ideas, skills and offerings concerning publishing, artist collaboration and whatever else come to mind. If you are a visual artist i would love to see your interpretation of the title of the series in whatever medium suittsyouwrite.
